1.verse: For Zion's sake I will not be silent, for Jerusalem's sake I will not be quiet, Until her vindication shines forth like the dawn and her victory like a burning torch.

2.verse: Nations shall behold your vindication, and all kings your glory; You shall be called by a new name pronounced by the mouth of the LORD.

3.verse: You shall be a glorious crown in the hand of the LORD, a royal diadem held by your God.

4.verse: No more shall men call you "Forsaken," or your land "Desolate," But you shall be called "My Delight," and your land "Espoused." For the LORD delights in you, and makes your land his spouse.

5.verse: As a young man marries a virgin, your Builder shall marry you; And as a bridegroom rejoices in his bride so shall your God rejoice in you.

6.verse: Upon your walls, O Jerusalem, I have stationed watchmen; Never, by day or by night, shall they be silent. O you who are to remind the LORD, take no rest

7.verse: And give no rest to him, until he re-establishes Jerusalem And makes of it the pride of the earth.

8.verse: The LORD has sworn by his right hand and by his mighty arm: No more will I give your grain as food to your enemies; Nor shall foreigners drink your wine, for which you toiled.

9.verse: But you who harvest the grain shall eat it, and you shall praise the LORD; You who gather the grapes shall drink the wine in the courts of my sanctuary.

10.verse: Pass through, pass through the gates, prepare the way for the people; Build up, build up the highway, clear it of stones, raise up a standard over the nations.

11.verse: See, the LORD proclaims to the ends of the earth: Say to daughter Zion, your savior comes! Here is his reward with him, his recompense before him.

12.verse: They shall be called the holy people, the redeemed of the LORD, And you shall be called "Frequented," a city that is not forsaken.

annotations.1: [2] New name: figurative expression for a new state of happiness; cf Rev 2:17; 3:12.
annotations.2: [6-7] Remind the LORD . . . give no rest to him: figuratively, as though to make certain that the Lord will remember his pledge to Jerusalem. Cf Luke 11:7-8
annotations.3: [10] The command is given to the workmen to begin the reconstruction of the city

1.verse: Listen to me, you who pursue justice, who seek the LORD; Look to the rock from which you were hewn, to the pit from which you were quarried;

2.verse: Look to Abraham, your father, and to Sarah, who gave you birth; When he was but one I called him, I blessed him and made him many.

3.verse: Yes, the LORD shall comfort Zion and have pity on all her ruins; Her deserts he shall make like Eden, her wasteland like the garden of the LORD; Joy and gladness shall be found in her, thanksgiving and the sound of song.

4.verse: Be attentive to me, my people; my folk, give ear to me. For law shall go forth from my presence, and my judgment, as the light of the peoples.

5.verse: I will make my justice come speedily; my salvation shall go forth (and my arm shall judge the nations); In me shall the coastlands hope, and my arm they shall await.

6.verse: Raise your eyes to the heavens, and look at the earth below; Though the heavens grow thin like smoke, the earth wears out like a garment and its inhabitants die like flies, My salvation shall remain forever and my justice shall never be dismayed.

7.verse: Hear me, you who know justice, you people who have my teaching at heart: Fear not the reproach of men, be not dismayed at their revilings.

8.verse: They shall be like a garment eaten by moths, like wool consumed by grubs; But my justice shall remain forever and my salvation, for all generations.

9.verse: Awake, awake, put on strength, O arm of the LORD! Awake as in the days of old, in ages long ago! Was it not you who crushed Rahab, you who pierced the dragon?

10.verse: Was it not you who dried up the sea, the waters of the great deep, Who made the depths of the sea into a way for the redeemed to pass over?

11.verse: Those whom the LORD has ransomed will return and enter Zion singing, crowned with everlasting joy; They will meet with joy and gladness, sorrow and mourning will flee.

12.verse: I, it is I who comfort you. Can you then fear mortal man, who is human only, to be looked upon as grass,

13.verse: And forget the LORD, your maker, who stretched out the heavens and laid the foundations of the earth? All the day you are in constant dread of the fury of the oppressor; But when he sets himself to destroy, what is there of the oppressor's fury?

14.verse: The oppressed shall soon be released; they shall not die and go down into the pit, nor shall they want for bread.

15.verse: For I am the LORD, your God, who stirs up the sea so that its waves roar; the LORD of hosts by name.

16.verse: I have put my words into your mouth and shielded you in the shadow of my hand, I, who stretched out the heavens, who laid the foundations of the earth, who say to Zion: You are my people.

17.verse: Awake, awake! Arise, O Jerusalem, You who drank at the LORD'S hand the cup of his wrath; Who drained to the dregs the bowl of staggering!

18.verse: She has no one to guide her of all the sons she bore; She has no one to grasp her by the hand, of all the sons she reared! -

19.verse: Your misfortunes are double; who is there to condole with you? Desolation and destruction, famine and sword! Who is there to comfort you?

20.verse: Your sons lie helpless at every street corner like antelopes in a net. They are filled with the wrath of the LORD, the rebuke of your God.

21.verse: But now, hear this, O afflicted one, drunk, but not with wine,

22.verse: Thus says the LORD, your Master, your God, who defends his people: See, I am taking from your hand the cup of staggering; The bowl of my wrath you shall no longer drink.

23.verse: I will put it into the hands of your tormentors, those who ordered you to bow down, that they might walk over you, While you offered your back like the ground, like the street for them to walk on.

annotations.1: [1] Rock . . . pit: your glorious ancestry.
annotations.2: [4-5] The conversion of the Gentiles
annotations.3: [6] God's salvation and justice are eternal, in contrast to the impermanence of the heavens and the earth: cf Matthew 24:35
annotations.4: [9] Rahab: see note on Isaiah 30:7. The dragon: see notes on Isaiah 27:1; Psalm 74:13
annotations.5: [10] Great deep: another reference to the primeval chaos of Genesis 1:2

1.verse: Woe to Ariel, Ariel, the city where David encamped! Add year to year, let the feasts come round.

2.verse: But I will bring distress upon Ariel, with mourning and grief. You shall be to me like Ariel,

3.verse: I will encamp like David against you; I will encircle you with outposts and set up siege works against you.

4.verse: Prostrate you shall speak from the earth, and from the base dust your words shall come. Your voice shall be like a ghost's from the earth, and your words like chirping from the dust.

5.verse: The horde of your arrogant shall be like fine dust, the horde of the tyrants like flying chaff. Then suddenly, in an instant,

6.verse: you shall be visited by the LORD of hosts, With thunder, earthquake, and great noise, whirlwind, storm, and the flame of consuming fire.

7.verse: Then like a dream, a vision in the night, Shall be the horde of all the nations who war against Ariel with all the earthworks of her besiegers.

8.verse: As when a hungry man dreams he is eating and awakens with an empty stomach, Or when a thirsty man dreams he is drinking and awakens faint and dry, So shall the horde of all the nations be, who make war against Zion.

9.verse: Be irresolute, stupefied; blind yourselves and stay blind! Be drunk, but not from wine, stagger, but not from strong drink!

10.verse: For the LORD has poured out on you a spirit of deep sleep. He has shut your eyes (the prophets) and covered your heads (the seers).

11.verse: For you the revelation of all this has become like the words of a sealed scroll. When it is handed to one who can read, with the request, "Read this," he replies, "I cannot; it is sealed."

12.verse: When it is handed to one who cannot read, with the request, "Read this," he replies, "I cannot read."

13.verse: The Lord said: Since this people draws near with words only and honors me with their lips alone, though their hearts are far from me, And their reverence for me has become routine observance of the precepts of men,

14.verse: Therefore I will again deal with this people in surprising and wondrous fashion: The wisdom of its wise men shall perish and the understanding of its prudent men be hid.

15.verse: Woe to those who would hide their plans too deep for the LORD! Who work in the dark, saying, "Who sees us, or who knows us?"

16.verse: Your perversity is as though the potter were taken to be the clay: As though what is made should say of its maker, "He made me not!" Or the vessel should say of the potter, "He does not understand."

17.verse: But a very little while, and Lebanon shall be changed into an orchard, and the orchard be regarded as a forest!

18.verse: On that day the deaf shall hear the words of a book; And out of gloom and darkness, the eyes of the blind shall see.

19.verse: The lowly will ever find joy in the LORD, and the poor rejoice in the Holy One of Israel.

20.verse: For the tyrant will be no more and the arrogant will have gone; All who are alert to do evil will be cut off,

21.verse: those whose mere word condemns a man, Who ensnare his defender at the gate, and leave the just man with an empty claim.

22.verse: Therefore thus says the LORD, the God of the house of Jacob, who redeemed Abraham: Now Jacob shall have nothing to be ashamed of, nor shall his face grow pale.

23.verse: When his children see the work of my hands in his midst, They shall keep my name holy; they shall reverence the Holy One of Jacob, and be in awe of the God of Israel.

24.verse: Those who err in spirit shall acquire understanding, and those who find fault shall receive instruction.

annotations.1: [1-2] Ariel: variously interpreted to mean "lion of God" or "hearth (altar) of God," a poetic name for Jerusalem; or perhaps to be read as Uru-el, "foundation of God," an archaic name for the Jebusite city of Jerusalem; like that Ariel, against which David encamped, it will be besieged by God.
annotations.2: Chirping: see note on Isaiah 8:19.
annotations.3: [7-8] Just when the Assyrians think their capture of Jerusalem to be certain, the Lord will snatch victory from their hands and save his city
annotations.4: [9-12] Jerusalem in her blindness refuses to believe God's revelation that she will be saved
annotations.5: [17-24] The prophet presents God's plan of redemption in terms of unheard-of natural phenomena as if such changes in nature took place, e.g., the change of the cedars of Lebanon into an orchard ( Isaiah 29:17)
annotations.6: [22] Who redeemed Abraham: by freeing him from the idolatry of his native land

1.verse: Oracle on the wastelands by the sea: Like whirlwinds sweeping in waves through the Negeb, there comes from the desert, from the fearful land,

2.verse: A cruel sight, revealed to me: the traitor betrays, the despoiler spoils. "Go up, Elam; besiege, O Media; I will put an end to all groaning!"

3.verse: Therefore my loins are filled with anguish, pangs have seized me like those of a woman in labor; I am too bewildered to hear, too dismayed to look.

4.verse: My mind reels, shuddering assails me; My yearning for twilight has turned into dread.

5.verse: They set the table, spread out the rugs; they eat, they drink. Rise up, O princes, oil the shield!

6.verse: For thus says my Lord to me: Go, station a watchman, let him tell what he sees.

7.verse: If he sees a chariot, a pair of horses, Someone riding an ass, someone riding a camel, Then let him pay heed, very close heed.

8.verse: Then the watchman cried, "On the watchtower, O my Lord, I stand constantly by day; And I stay at my post through all the watches of the night.

9.verse: Here he comes now: a single chariot, a pair of horses; He calls out and says, 'Fallen, fallen is Babylon, And all the images of her gods are smashed to the ground.'"

10.verse: O my people who have been threshed, beaten on my threshing floor! What I have heard from the LORD of hosts, The God of Israel, I have announced to you.

11.verse: Oracle on Edom: They call to me from Seir, "Watchman, how much longer the night? Watchman, how much longer the night?"

12.verse: The watchman replies, "Morning has come, and again night. If you will ask, ask; come back again."

13.verse: Oracle on Arabia: In the thicket in the nomad country spend the night, O caravans of Dedanites.

14.verse: Meet the thirsty, bring them water; you who dwell in the land of Tema, greet the fugitives with bread.

15.verse: They flee from the sword, from the whetted sword; From the taut bow, from the fury of battle.

16.verse: For thus says the Lord to me: In another year, like those of a hireling, all the glory of Kedar shall come to an end.

17.verse: Few of Kedar's stalwart archers shall remain, for the LORD, the God of Israel, has spoken.

annotations.1: [1] Wastelands by the sea: Babylonia. Negeb: the desert south of Judah.
annotations.2: [2] Elam . . . Media: nations which, under the leadership of Cyrus, captured Babylon in 538 B.C. End to all groaning: those who were captive of Babylon shall be freed
annotations.3: [5] Babylon is destroyed while its leaders are feasting; cf Daniel 5. Oil the shield: shields were oiled and greased so as to divert blows more easily
annotations.4: [11-12] Seir: another name for Edom. The Edomites ask the prophet how much longer they must suffer (the night of suffering); he answers ambiguously: "Liberation (morning) and further suffering (night)," but perhaps they will later receive a more encouraging answer (ask, come back again)
annotations.5: [13-14] Arabia: that is, the nomad country. Dedanites: an Arab tribe associated with Edom and Tema, and living east of the Red Sea; cf Genesis 10:7; 25:3; Jeremiah 25:23
annotations.6: [16] Year . . . of a hireling: see note on 16:14. Kedar: a nomad tribe in Arabia; cf Isaiah 42:11; 60:7; Psalm 120:5

1.verse: Cry out full-throated and unsparingly, lift up your voice like a trumpet blast; Tell my people their wickedness, and the house of Jacob their sins.

2.verse: They seek me day after day, and desire to know my ways, Like a nation that has done what is just and not abandoned the law of their God; They ask me to declare what is due them, pleased to gain access to God.

3.verse: "Why do we fast, and you do not see it? afflict ourselves, and you take no note of it?" Lo, on your fast day you carry out your own pursuits, and drive all your laborers.

4.verse: Yes, your fast ends in quarreling and fighting, striking with wicked claw. Would that today you might fast so as to make your voice heard on high!

5.verse: Is this the manner of fasting I wish, of keeping a day of penance: That a man bow his head like a reed, and lie in sackcloth and ashes? Do you call this a fast, a day acceptable to the LORD?

6.verse: This, rather, is the fasting that I wish: releasing those bound unjustly, untying the thongs of the yoke; Setting free the oppressed, breaking every yoke;

7.verse: Sharing your bread with the hungry, sheltering the oppressed and the homeless; Clothing the naked when you see them, and not turning your back on your own.

8.verse: Then your light shall break forth like the dawn, and your wound shall quickly be healed; Your vindication shall go before you, and the glory of the LORD shall be your rear guard.

9.verse: Then you shall call, and the LORD will answer, you shall cry for help, and he will say: Here I am! If you remove from your midst oppression, false accusation and malicious speech;

10.verse: If you bestow your bread on the hungry and satisfy the afflicted; Then light shall rise for you in the darkness, and the gloom shall become for you like midday;

11.verse: Then the LORD will guide you always and give you plenty even on the parched land. He will renew your strength, and you shall be like a watered garden, like a spring whose water never fails.

12.verse: The ancient ruins shall be rebuilt for your sake, and the foundations from ages past you shall raise up; "Repairer of the breach," they shall call you, "Restorer of ruined homesteads."

13.verse: If you hold back your foot on the sabbath from following your own pursuits on my holy day; If you call the sabbath a delight, and the LORD'S holy day honorable; If you honor it by not following your ways, seeking your own interests, or speaking with malice -

14.verse: Then you shall delight in the LORD, and I will make you ride on the heights of the earth; I will nourish you with the heritage of Jacob, your father, for the mouth of the LORD has spoken.

annotations.1: [1] This command is directed to the prophet.
annotations.2: [2-14] Merely external worship does not avail with God; it must be joined to internal sincerity

1.verse: Oracle on Egypt: See, the LORD is riding on a swift cloud on his way to Egypt; The idols of Egypt tremble before him, the hearts of the Egyptians melt within them.

2.verse: I will rouse Egypt against Egypt: brother will war against brother, Neighbor against neighbor, city against city, kingdom against kindgom.

3.verse: The courage of the Egyptians ebbs away within them, and I will bring to nought their counsel; They shall consult idols and charmers, ghosts and spirits.

4.verse: I will deliver Egypt into the power of a cruel master, A harsh king who shall rule over them, says the Lord, the LORD of hosts.

5.verse: The waters shall be drained from the sea, the river shall shrivel and dry up;

6.verse: Its streams shall become foul, and the canals of Egypt shall dwindle and dry up. Reeds and rushes shall wither away,

7.verse: and bulrushes on the bank of the Nile; All the sown land along the Nile shall dry up and blow away, and be no more.

8.verse: The fishermen shall mourn and lament, all who cast hook in the Nile; Those who spread their nets in the water shall pine away.

9.verse: The linen-workers shall be disappointed, the combers and weavers shall turn pale;

10.verse: The spinners shall be crushed, all the hired laborers shall be despondent.

11.verse: Utter fools are the princes of Zoan! the wisest of Pharaoh's advisers give stupid counsel. How can you say to Pharaoh, "I am a disciple of wise men, of ancient kings"?

12.verse: Where then are your wise men? Let them tell you and make known What the LORD of hosts has planned against Egypt.

13.verse: The princes of Zoan have become fools, the princes of Memphis have been deceived. The chiefs of her tribes have led Egypt astray.

14.verse: The LORD has prepared among them a spirit of dizziness, And they have made Egypt stagger in whatever she does, as a drunkard staggers in his vomit.

15.verse: Egypt shall have no work to do for head or tail, palm branch or reed.

16.verse: On that day the Egyptians shall be like women, trembling with fear, because of the LORD of hosts shaking his fist at them.

17.verse: And the land of Judah shall be a terror to the Egyptians. Every time they remember Judah, they shall stand in dread because of the plan which the LORD of hosts has in mind for them.

18.verse: On that day there shall be five cities in the land of Egypt speaking the language of Canaan and swearing by the LORD of hosts; one shall be called "City of the Sun."

19.verse: On that day there shall be an altar to the LORD in the land of Egypt, and a sacred pillar to the LORD near the boundary.

20.verse: It shall be a sign and a witness to the LORD of hosts in the land of Egypt, when they cry out to the LORD against their oppressors, and he sends them a savior to defend and deliver them.

21.verse: The LORD shall make himself known to Egypt, and the Egyptians shall know the LORD in that day; they shall offer sacrifices and oblations, and fulfill the vows they make to the LORD.

22.verse: Although the LORD shall smite Egypt severely, he shall heal them; they shall turn to the LORD and he shall be won over and heal them.

23.verse: On that day there shall be a highway from Egypt to Assyria; the Assyrians shall enter Egypt, and the Egyptians enter Assyria, and Egypt shall serve Assyria.

24.verse: On that day Israel shall be a third party with Egypt and Assyria, a blessing in the midst of the land,

25.verse: when the LORD of hosts blesses it: "Blessed be my people Egypt, and the work of my hands Assyria, and my inheritance, Israel."

annotations.1: [4] Cruel master: the king of Assyria.
annotations.2: [11,13] Zoan, later known as Tanis, and Memphis (in Hebrew, Noph) were the key cities of the Nile Delta
annotations.3: [15] Head or tail, palm branch or reed: the leaders or the people; cf Isaiah 9:13, 14
annotations.4: [18] Five cities: colonies of Jews living together and speaking their languages, Hebrew and Aramaic; cf Jer 43. City of the Sun: the meaning is uncertain, but the reference seems to be to the city known later as Heliopolis

1.verse: Come down, sit in the dust, O virgin daughter Babylon; Sit on the ground, dethroned, O daughter of the Chaldeans. No longer shall you be called dainty and delicate.

2.verse: Take the millstone and grind flour, remove your veil; Strip off your train, bare your legs, pass through the streams.

3.verse: Your nakedness shall be uncovered and your shame be seen; I will take vengeance, I will yield to no entreaty, says our redeemer,

4.verse: Whose name is the LORD of hosts, the Holy One of Israel.

5.verse: Go into darkness and sit in silence, O daughter of the Chaldeans, No longer shall you be called sovereign mistress of kingdoms.

6.verse: Angry at my people, I profaned my inheritance, And I gave them into your hand; but you showed them no mercy, And upon old men you laid a very heavy yoke.

7.verse: You said, "I shall remain always, a sovereign mistress forever!" But you did not lay these things to heart, you disregarded their outcome.

8.verse: Now hear this, voluptuous one, enthroned securely, Saying to yourself, "I, and no one else! I shall never be a widow, or suffer the loss of my children" -

9.verse: Both these things shall come to you suddenly, in a single day: Complete bereavement and widowhood shall come upon you For your many sorceries and the great number of your spells;

10.verse: Because you felt secure in your wickedness, and said, "No one sees me." Your wisdom and your knowledge led you astray, And you said to yourself, "I, and no one else!"

11.verse: But upon you shall come evil you will not know how to predict; Disaster shall befall you which you cannot allay. Suddenly there shall come upon you ruin which you will not expect.

12.verse: Keep up, now, your spells and your many sorceries. Perhaps you can make them avail, perhaps you can strike terror!

13.verse: You wearied yourself with many consultations, at which you toiled from your youth; Let the astrologers stand forth to save you, the stargazers who forecast at each new moon what would happen to you.

14.verse: Lo, they are like stubble, fire consumes them; They cannot save themselves from the spreading flames. This is no warming ember, no fire to sit before.

15.verse: Thus do your wizards serve you with whom you have toiled from your youth; Each wanders his own way, with none to save you.

annotations.1: [1-15] A taunt-song, mocking Babylon, once queen of the nations, now made a slave girl.
annotations.2: [9-13,15] Babylon was known for its sorcery and astrology

1.verse: At that time when Merodach-baladan, son of Baladan, king of Babylon, heard that Hezekiah had recovered from his sickness, he sent letters and gifts to him.

2.verse: Hezekiah was pleased at this, and therefore showed the messengers his treasury, the silver and gold, the spices and fine oil, his whole armory, and everything that was in his storerooms; there was nothing in his house or in his whole realm that he did not show them.

3.verse: Then Isaiah the prophet came to King Hezekiah and asked him, "What did these men say to you? Where did they come from?" Hezekiah answered, "They came to me from a distant land, from Babylon."

4.verse: "What did they see in your house?" he asked. Hezekiah replied, "They saw everything in my house; there is nothing in my storerooms that I did not show them."

5.verse: Then Isaiah said to Hezekiah, "Hear the word of the LORD of hosts:

6.verse: Behold, the days shall come when all that is in your house, and everything that your fathers have stored up until this day, shall be carried off to Babylon; nothing shall be left, says the LORD.

7.verse: Some of your own bodily descendants shall be taken and made servants in the palace of the king of Babylon."

8.verse: Hezekiah replied to Isaiah, "The word of the LORD which you have spoken is favorable." For he thought, "There will be peace and security in my lifetime."

annotations.1: [1] Merodach-baladan: twice king of Babylon, probably from 721 to 710 B.C., and again for nine months, in 704-703. This visit of his messengers, certainly before 701, was in reality a political one. Babylon hoped to lead an anti-Assyrian confederation composed of neighboring states.
annotations.2: [6] Because Judah preferred to follow a pro-Babylonian policy, instead of trusting in God, it would later be exiled to Babylon
annotations.3: [8] Favorable: for the exile would not occur in his lifetime

1.verse: This is what Isaiah, son of Amoz, saw concerning Judah and Jerusalem.

2.verse: In days to come, The mountain of the LORD'S house shall be established as the highest mountain and raised above the hills. All nations shall stream toward it;

3.verse: many peoples shall come and say: "Come, let us climb the LORD'S mountain, to the house of the God of Jacob, That he may instruct us in his ways, and we may walk in his paths." For from Zion shall go forth instruction, and the word of the LORD from Jerusalem.

4.verse: He shall judge between the nations, and impose terms on many peoples. They shall beat their swords into plowshares and their spears into pruning hooks; One nation shall not raise the sword against another, nor shall they train for war again.

5.verse: O house of Jacob, come, let us walk in the light of the LORD!

6.verse: You have abandoned your people, the house of Jacob, Because they are filled with fortunetellers and soothsayers, like the Philistines; they covenant with strangers.

7.verse: Their land is full of silver and gold, and there is no end to their treasures; Their land is full of horses, and there is no end to their chariots.

8.verse: Their land is full of idols; they worship the works of their hands, that which their fingers have made.

9.verse: But man is abased, each one brought low. (Do not pardon them!)

10.verse: Get behind the rocks, hide in the dust, From the terror of the LORD and the splendor of his majesty!

11.verse: The haughty eyes of man will be lowered, the arrogance of men will be abased, and the LORD alone will be exalted, on that day.

12.verse: For the LORD of hosts will have his day against all that is proud and arrogant, all that is high, and it will be brought low;

13.verse: Yes, against all the cedars of Lebanon and all the oaks of Bashan,

14.verse: Against all the lofty mountains and all the high hills,

15.verse: Against every lofty tower and every fortified wall,

16.verse: Against all the ships of Tarshish and all stately vessels.

17.verse: Human pride will be abased, the arrogance of men brought low, And the LORD alone will be exalted, on that day.

18.verse: The idols will perish forever.

19.verse: Men will go into caves in the rocks and into holes in the earth, From the terror of the LORD and the splendor of his majesty, when he arises to overawe the earth.

20.verse: On that day men will throw to the moles and the bats the idols of silver and gold which they made for worship.

21.verse: They go into caverns in the rocks and into crevices in the cliffs, From the terror of the LORD and the splendor of his majesty, when he arises to overawe the earth.

22.verse: As for you, let man alone, in whose nostrils is but a breath; for what is he worth?

annotations.1: [1] An editorial addition introducing Isaiah 2-5.
annotations.2: [2-4] The messianic destiny which ensures Judah's later restoration. In the messianic kingdom the prophets generally see the Lord's house as the seat of authority and the source of clear and certain doctrine; also, its rule willingly accepted by all peoples, maintained by spiritual sanctions, and tending to universal peace. This passage is found substantially unchanged in Micah 4:1-3; it probably, although not certainly, has Isaiah as its author
annotations.3: [3] Zion . . . Jerusalem: types of the earthly center of the messianic kingdom
annotations.4: [6] Fortune-tellers and soothsayers: divination was strictly forbidden; cf Deut 18:9-14
annotations.5: [11] That day: the day of the Lord, a day of retribution, often referred to, especially by the minor prophets, and described in terms of natural phenomena: earthquake, fire, storm
annotations.6: [13] Lebanon: Mount Lebanon in Syria, famed for its cedars. Bashan: the wooded uplands east of the Jordan River

1.verse: Lo, the LORD empties the land and lays it waste; he turns it upside down, scattering its inhabitants:

2.verse: Layman and priest alike, servant and master, The maid as her mistress, the buyer as the seller, The lender as the borrower, the creditor as the debtor.

3.verse: The earth is utterly laid waste, utterly stripped, for the LORD has decreed this thing.

4.verse: The earth mourns and fades, the world languishes and fades; both heaven and earth languish.

5.verse: The earth is polluted because of its inhabitants, who have transgressed laws, violated statutes, broken the ancient covenant.

6.verse: Therefore a curse devours the earth, and its inhabitants pay for their guilt; Therefore they who dwell on earth turn pale, and few men are left.

7.verse: The wine mourns, the vine languishes, all the merry-hearted groan.

8.verse: Stilled are the cheerful timbrels, ended the shouts of the jubilant, stilled is the cheerful harp.

9.verse: They cannot sing and drink wine; strong drink is bitter to those who partake of it.

10.verse: Broken down is the city of chaos, shut against entry, every house.

11.verse: In the streets they cry out for lack of wine; all joy has disappeared and cheer has left the land.

12.verse: In the city nothing remains but ruin; its gates are battered and desolate.

13.verse: Thus it is within the land, and among the peoples, As with an olive tree after it is beaten, as with a gleaning when the vintage is done.

14.verse: These lift up their voice in acclaim; from the sea they proclaim the majesty of the LORD:

4.verse: for before the child knows how to call his father or mother by name, the wealth of Damascus and the spoil of Samaria shall be carried off by the king of Assyria.

6.verse: Because this people has rejected the waters of Shiloah that flow gently, And melts with fear before the loftiness of Rezin and Remaliah's son,

annotations.1: [1] Ordinary letters: easily read by all. Maher-shalal-hash-baz: a symbolic name to be given to another son of Isaiah (v 3); it means "quick spoils; speedy plunder," and describes what the Assyrians will do.
annotations.2: [2] Reliable witnesses: who would testify that Isaiah had indeed prophesied the future destruction. Uriah the priest: cf 2 Kings 16:10
annotations.3: [3] The prophetess: wife of Isaiah
annotations.4: [6-8] This people: Judah. Waters of Shiloah: the stream that flows into the pool of Shiloah in Jerusalem, its slow current symbolizing the silent, divine protection which Judah has rejected. God will therefore summon the mighty Assyrian army, symbolized by the River (Euphrates), to devastate Judah, which, however, will not be entirely destroyed, because it is the land of Immanuel
annotations.5: [10] The plan of Israel's enemies will be thwarted because, as the name "Immanuel" signifies, With us is God
annotations.6: [16] Kept among my disciples: for preservation and transmission
annotations.7: [18] Signs: Isaiah and his sons had symbolic names
annotations.8: [19] Chirp and mutter: a mocking reference to the sounds uttered by necromancers, as if the dead were speaking; all such practices were forbidden
annotations.9: [21,22] These verses have been transposed and placed within Isaiah 14:25 which affords the context in which they can be understood
annotations.10: [23] (23)Zebulun . . . Naphtali: northern Palestine, which was first to be attacked by the Assyrians; God, however, redeems it, as he redeems all his people. Seaward road: from Damascus, across southern Galilee to the Mediterranean Sea. District of the Gentiles: northern Galilee, inhabited by pagans; cf Joshua 20:7; Isaiah 9:1; Matthew 4:15-16 refers to this, since Jesus began his public mission in Galilee

1.verse: Let me now sing of my friend, my friend's song concerning his vineyard. My friend had a vineyard on a fertile hillside;

2.verse: He spaded it, cleared it of stones, and planted the choicest vines; Within it he built a watchtower, and hewed out a wine press. Then he looked for the crop of grapes, but what it yielded was wild grapes.

3.verse: Now, inhabitants of Jerusalem and men of Judah, judge between me and my vineyard:

4.verse: What more was there to do for my vineyard that I had not done? Why, when I looked for the crop of grapes, did it bring forth wild grapes?

5.verse: Now, I will let you know what I mean to do to my vineyard: Take away its hedge, give it to grazing, break through its wall, let it be trampled!

6.verse: Yes, I will make it a ruin: it shall not be pruned or hoed, but overgrown with thorns and briers; I will command the clouds not to send rain upon it.

7.verse: The vineyard of the LORD of hosts is the house of Israel, and the men of Judah are his cherished plant; He looked for judgment, but see, bloodshed! for justice, but hark, the outcry!

8.verse: Woe to you who join house to house, who connect field with field, Till no room remains, and you are left to dwell alone in the midst of the land!

9.verse: In my hearing the LORD of hosts has sworn: Many houses shall be in ruins, large ones and fine, with no one to live in them.

10.verse: Ten acres of vineyard shall yield but one liquid measure, And a homer of seed shall yield but an ephah.

17.verse: Lambs shall graze there at pasture, and kids shall eat in the ruins of the rich.

11.verse: Woe to those who demand strong drink as soon as they rise in the morning, And linger into the night while wine inflames them!

12.verse: With harp and lyre, timbrel and flute, they feast on wine; But what the LORD does, they regard not, the work of his hands they see not.

13.verse: Therefore my people go into exile, because they do not understand; Their nobles die of hunger, and their masses are parched with thirst.

14.verse: Therefore the nether world enlarges its throat and opens its maw without limit; Down go their nobility and their masses, their throngs and their revelry.

15.verse: Men shall be abased, each one brought low, and the eyes of the haughty lowered,

16.verse: But the LORD of hosts shall be exalted by his judgment, and God the Holy shall be shown holy by his justice.

18.verse: Woe to those who tug at guilt with cords of perversity, and at sin as if with cart ropes!

19.verse: To those who say, "Let him make haste and speed his work, that we may see it; On with the plan of the Holy One of Israel! let it come to pass, that we may know it!"

20.verse: Woe to those who call evil good, and good evil, who change darkness into light, and light into darkness, who change bitter into sweet, and sweet into bitter!

21.verse: Woe to those who are wise in their own sight, and prudent in their own esteem!

22.verse: Woe to the champions at drinking wine, the valiant at mixing strong drink!

23.verse: To those who acquit the guilty for bribes, and deprive the just man of his rights!

24.verse: Therefore, as the tongue of fire licks up stubble, as dry grass shrivels in the flame, Even so their root shall become rotten and their blossom scatter like dust; For they have spurned the law of the LORD of hosts, and scorned the word of the Holy One of Israel.

25.verse: Therefore the wrath of the LORD blazes against his people, he raises his hand to strike them; When the mountains quake, their corpses shall be like refuse in the streets. For all this, his wrath is not turned back, and his hand is still outstretched.

26.verse: He will give a signal to a far-off nation, and whistle to them from the ends of the earth; speedily and promptly will they come.

27.verse: None of them will stumble with weariness, none will slumber and none will sleep. None will have his waist belt loose, nor the thong of his sandal broken.

1.verse: Hear this, O house of Jacob called by the name Israel, sprung from the stock of Judah, You who swear by the name of the LORD and invoke the God of Israel without sincerity or justice,

2.verse: Though you are named after the holy city and rely on the God of Israel, whose name is the LORD of hosts.

3.verse: Things of the past I foretold long ago, they went forth from my mouth, I let you hear of them; then suddenly I took action and they came to be.

4.verse: Because I know that you are stubborn and that your neck is an iron sinew and your forehead bronze,

5.verse: I foretold them to you of old; before they took place I let you hear of them, That you might not say, "My idol did them, my statue, my molten image commanded them."

6.verse: Now that you have heard, look at all this; must you not admit it? From now on I announce new things to you, hidden events of which you knew not.

7.verse: Now, not long ago, they are brought into being, and beforetime you did not hear of them, so that you cannot claim to have known them;

8.verse: You neither heard nor knew, they did not reach your ears beforehand. Yes, I know you are utterly treacherous, a rebel you were called from birth.

9.verse: For the sake of my name I restrain my anger, for the sake of my renown I hold it back from you, lest I should destroy you.

10.verse: See, I have refined you like silver, tested you in the furnace of affliction.

11.verse: For my sake, for my own sake, I do this; why should I suffer profanation? My glory I will not give to another.

12.verse: Listen to me, Jacob, Israel, whom I named! I, it is I who am the first, and also the last am I.

13.verse: Yes, my hand laid the foundations of the earth; my right hand spread out the heavens. When I call them, they stand forth at once.

14.verse: All of you assemble and listen: Who among you foretold these things? The LORD'S friend shall do his will against Babylon and the progeny of Chaldea.

15.verse: I myself have spoken, I have called him, I have brought him, and his way succeeds!

16.verse: Come near to me and hear this! Not from the beginning did I speak it in secret; At the time it comes to pass, I am present: "Now the Lord GOD has sent me, and his spirit."

17.verse: Thus says the LORD, your redeemer, the Holy One of Israel: I, the LORD, your God, teach you what is for your good, and lead you on the way you should go.

18.verse: If you would hearken to my commandments, your prosperity would be like a river, and your vindication like the waves of the sea;

19.verse: Your descendants would be like the sand, and those born of your stock like its grains, Their name never cut off or blotted out from my presence.

20.verse: Go forth from Babylon, flee from Chaldea! With shouts of joy proclaim this, make it known; Publish it to the ends of the earth, and say, "The LORD has redeemed his servant Jacob.

21.verse: They did not thirst when he led them through dry lands; Water from the rock he set flowing for them; he cleft the rock, and waters welled forth."

22.verse: (There is no peace for the wicked, says the LORD.)

1.verse: Oracle of the Valley of Vision: What is the matter with you now, that you have gone up, all of you, to the housetops,

2.verse: O city full of noise and chaos, O wanton town! Your slain are not slain with the sword, nor killed in battle.

3.verse: All your leaders fled away together, fled afar off; All who were in you were captured together, captured without the use of a bow.

4.verse: At this I say: Turn away from me, let me weep bitterly; Do not try to comfort me for the ruin of the daughter of my people.

5.verse: It is a day of panic, rout and confusion, from the Lord, the GOD of hosts, in the Valley of Vision. Walls crash; they cry for help to the mountains.

6.verse: Elam takes up the quivers, Aram mounts the horses, and Kir uncovers the shields.

7.verse: Your choice valleys are filled with chariots, and horses are posted at the gates,

8.verse: and shelter over Judah is removed. On that day you looked to the weapons in the House of the Forest;

9.verse: you saw that the breaches in the City of David were many; you collected the water of the lower pool.

10.verse: You numbered the houses of Jerusalem, tearing some down to strengthen the wall;

11.verse: you made a reservoir between the two walls for the water of the old pool. But you did not look to the city's Maker, nor did you consider him who built it long ago.

12.verse: On that day the Lord, the GOD of hosts, called on you To weep and mourn, to shave your head and put on sackcloth.

13.verse: But look! you feast and celebrate, you slaughter oxen and butcher sheep, You eat meat and drink wine: "Eat and drink, for tomorrow we die!"

14.verse: This reaches the ears of the LORD of hosts - You shall not be pardoned this wickedness till you die, says the Lord, the GOD of hosts.

15.verse: Thus says the Lord, the GOD of hosts: Up, go to that official, Shebna, master of the palace,

16.verse: Who has hewn for himself a sepulcher on a height and carved his tomb in the rock: "What are you doing here, and what people have you here, that here you have hewn for yourself a tomb?"

17.verse: The LORD shall hurl you down headlong, mortal man! He shall grip you firmly

18.verse: And roll you up and toss you like a ball into an open land To perish there, you and the chariots you glory in, you disgrace to your master's house!

19.verse: I will thrust you from your office and pull you down from your station.

20.verse: On that day I will summon my servant Eliakim, son of Hilkiah;

21.verse: I will clothe him with your robe, and gird him with your sash, and give over to him your authority. He shall be a father to the inhabitants of Jerusalem, and to the house of Judah.

22.verse: I will place the key of the House of David on his shoulder; when he opens, no one shall shut, when he shuts, no one shall open.

23.verse: I will fix him like a peg in a sure spot, to be a place of honor for his family;

24.verse: On him shall hang all the glory of his family: descendants and offspring, all the little dishes, from bowls to jugs.

25.verse: On that day, says the LORD of hosts, the peg fixed in a sure spot shall give way, break off and fall, and the weight that hung on it shall be done away with; for the LORD has spoken.

annotations.1: [1-8] Valley of Vision: while the people live in revelry and disorder, the prophet foresees the impending doom of the city.
annotations.2: [6] Elam, Aram, Kir: all allies of Assyria. Kir: perhaps the same people referred to in Amos 1:5
annotations.3: [8-11] Defense measures, in which the inhabitants of Jerusalem placed their trust instead of relying on God. House of the Forest: an armory built by Solomon; its columns of wood suggested the trees of a forest; cf 1 Kings 7:2; 10:17
annotations.4: [15] Shebna: referred to as the scribe in Isaiah 36:3
annotations.5: [20] Eliakim: also referred to in Isaiah 36:3; he is described as loyal to God
annotations.6: [22] Key: symbol of authority; cf Matthew 16:19; Rev 3:7
annotations.7: [24-25] If Eliakim should anger God, he and his family (compared here to dishes, bowls and jugs) will suffer disaster

1.verse: Lo, the hand of the LORD is not too short to save, nor his ear too dull to hear.

2.verse: Rather, it is your crimes that separate you from your God, It is your sins that make him hide his face so that he will not hear you.

3.verse: For your hands are stained with blood, your fingers with guilt; Your lips speak falsehood, and your tongue utters deceit.

4.verse: No one brings suit justly, no one pleads truthfully; They trust in emptiness and tell lies; they conceive mischief and bring forth malice.

5.verse: They hatch adders' eggs, and weave spiders' webs: Whoever eats their eggs will die, if one of them is pressed, it will hatch as a viper;

6.verse: Their webs cannot serve as clothing, nor can they cover themselves with their works. Their works are evil works, and deeds of violence come from their hands.

7.verse: Their feet run to evil, and they are quick to shed innocent blood; Their thoughts are destructive thoughts, plunder and ruin are on their highways.

8.verse: The way of peace they know not, and there is nothing that is right in their paths; Their ways they have made crooked, whoever treads them knows no peace.

9.verse: That is why right is far from us and justice does not reach us. We look for light, and lo, darkness; for brightness, but we walk in gloom!

10.verse: Like blind men we grope along the wall, like people without eyes we feel our way. We stumble at midday as at dusk, in Stygian darkness, like the dead.

11.verse: We all growl like bears, like doves we moan without ceasing. We look for right, but it is not there; for salvation, and it is far from us.

12.verse: For our offenses before you are many, our sins bear witness against us. Yes, our offenses are present to us, and our crimes we know:

verses.1:
Isaiah
Introduction
The greatest of the prophets appeared at a critical moment of Israel's history. The second half of the eighth century B.C. witnessed the collapse of the northern kingdom under the hammerlike blows of Assyria (722), while Jerusalem itself saw the army of Sennacherib drawn up before its walls (701). In the year that Uzziah, king of Judah, died (742), Isaiah received his call to the prophetic office in the Temple of Jerusalem. Close attention should be given to Isa 6, where this divine summons to be the ambassador of the Most High is circumstantially described
The vision of the Lord enthroned in glory stamps an indelible character on Isaiah's ministry and provides the key to the understanding of his message. The majesty, holiness and glory of the Lord took possession of his spirit and, conversely, he gained a new awareness of human pettiness and sinfulness. The enormous abyss between God's sovereign holiness and man's sin overwhelmed the prophet. Only the purifying coal of the seraphim could cleanse his lips and prepare him for acceptance of the call: "Here I am, send me!"
The ministry of Isaiah may be divided into three periods, covering the reigns of Jotham (742-735), Ahaz (735-715), and Hezekiah (715-687). To the first period belong, for the most part, the early oracles (Isa 1-5) which exposed the moral breakdown of Judah and its capital, Jerusalem. With the accession of Ahaz, the prophet became adviser to the king, whose throne was threatened by the Syro-Ephraimite coalition. Rejecting the plea of Isaiah for faith and courage, the weak Ahaz turned to Assyria for help. From this period came the majority of messianic oracles found in the section of Immanuel prophecies (Isa 6-12)
Hezekiah succeeded his father and undertook a religious reform which Isaiah undoubtedly supported. But the old intrigues began again, and the king was soon won over to the pro-Egyptian party. Isaiah denounced this "covenant with death" and again summoned Judah to faith in Yahweh as her only hope. But it was too late; the revolt had already begun. Assyria acted quickly and her army, after ravaging Judah, laid siege to Jerusalem (701). "I shut up Hezekiah like a bird in his cage," boasts the famous inscription of Sennacherib. But Yahweh delivered the city, as Isaiah had promised: God is the Lord of history, and Assyria but an instrument in his hands
Little is known about the last days of this great religious leader, whose oracles, of singular poetic beauty and power, constantly reminded his wayward people of their destiny and the fidelity of Yahweh to his promises
The complete Book of Isaiah is an anthology of poems composed chiefly by the great prophet, but also by disciples, some of whom came many years after Isaiah. In 1-39 most of the oracles come from Isaiah and faithfully reflect the situation in eighth-century Judah. To disciples deeply influenced by the prophet belong sections such as the Apocalypse of Isaiah (Isa 24-27), the oracles against Babylon (Isa 13-14), and probably the poems of Isa 34-35
Isa 40-55, sometimes called the Deutero-Isaiah, are generally attributed to an anonymous poet who prophesied toward the end of the Babylonian exile. From this section come the great messianic oracles known as the songs of the Servant, whose mysterious destiny of suffering and glorification is fulfilled in the passion and glorification of Christ. Isa 56-66 contain oracles from a later period and were composed by disciples who inherited the spirit and continued the work of the great prophet
The principal divisions of the Book of Isaiah are the following
A. The Book of Judgment
I. Indictment of Israel and Judah ( Isaiah 1:1-5, 30)
II. Immanuel Prophecies ( Isaiah 6:1- 12:6)
III. Oracles against the Pagan Nations ( Isaiah 13:1- 23:18)
IV. Apocalypse of Isaiah ( Isaiah 24:1- 27:13)
V. The Lord Alone, Israel's and Judah's Salvation ( Isaiah 28:1- 33:24)
VI. The Lord, Zion's Avenger ( Isaiah 34:1- 35:10)
VII. Historical Appendix ( Isaiah 36:1- 39:8)
B. The Book of Consolation
I. The Lord's Glory in Israel's Liberation ( Isaiah 40:1- 48:21)
II. Expiation of Sin, Spiritual Liberation of Israel ( Isaiah 49:1- 55:13)
III. Return of the First Captives ( Isaiah 56:1- 66:24)

3.verse: Therefore a strong people will honor you, fierce nations will fear you.

4.verse: For you are a refuge to the poor, a refuge to the needy in distress; Shelter from the rain, shade from the heat. As with the cold rain,

5.verse: as with the desert heat, even so you quell the uproar of the wanton.

11.verse: He will stretch forth his hands in Moab as a swimmer extends his hands to swim; He will bring low their pride as his hands sweep over them.
