1.verse: When King Hezekiah heard this, he tore his garments, wrapped himself in sackcloth, and went into the temple of the LORD.

2.verse: He sent Eliakim, the master of the palace, and Shebna the scribe, and the elders of the priests, wrapped in sackcloth, to tell the prophet Isaiah, son of Amoz:

3.verse: "Thus says Hezekiah: 'This is a day of distress, of rebuke, and of disgrace. Children are at the point of birth, but there is no strength to bring them forth.

4.verse: Perhaps the LORD, your God, will hear the words of the commander, whom his master, the king of Assyria, sent to taunt the living God, and will rebuke him for the words which the LORD, your God, has heard. Send up a prayer for the remnant that is here.'"

5.verse: When the servants of King Hezekiah had come to Isaiah,

6.verse: he said to them: "Tell this to your master: 'Thus says the LORD: Do not be frightened by the words you have heard, with which the servants of the king of Assyria have blasphemed me.

7.verse: I am about to put in him such a spirit that, when he hears a certain report, he will return to his own land, and there I will cause him to fall by the sword.'"

8.verse: When the commander returned to Lachish and heard that the king of Assyria had left there, he found him besieging Libnah.

9.verse: The king of Assyria heard a report that Tirhakah, king of Ethiopia, had come out to fight against him. Again he sent envoys to Hezekiah with this message: "Thus shall you say to Hezekiah, king of Judah:

10.verse: 'Do not let your God on whom you rely deceive you by saying that Jerusalem will not be handed over to the king of Assyria.

11.verse: You yourself have heard what the kings of Assyria have done to all the countries: They doomed them! Will you, then, be saved?

12.verse: Did the gods of the nations whom my fathers destroyed save them? Gozen, Haran, Rezeph, and the Edenites in Telassar?

13.verse: Where is the king of Hamath, the king of Arpad, or a king of the cities of Sepharvaim, Hena or Ivvah?'"

14.verse: Hezekiah took the letter from the hand of the messengers and read it; then he went up to the temple of the LORD, and spreading it out before him,

15.verse: he prayed to the LORD:

16.verse: "O LORD of hosts, God of Israel, enthroned upon the cherubim! You alone are God over all the kingdoms of the earth. You have made the heavens and the earth.

17.verse: Incline your ear, O LORD, and listen! Open your eyes, O LORD and see! Hear all the words of the letter that Sennacherib sent to taunt the living God.

18.verse: Truly, O LORD, the kings of Assyria have laid waste all the nations and their lands,

19.verse: and cast their gods into the fire; they destroyed them because they were not gods but the work of human hands, wood and stone.

20.verse: Therefore, O LORD, our God, save us from his hand, that all the kingdoms of the earth may know that you, O LORD, alone are God."

21.verse: Then Isaiah, son of Amoz, sent this message to Hezekiah: Thus says the LORD, the God of Israel: In answer to your prayer for help against Sennacherib, king of Assyria,

22.verse: this is the word the LORD has spoken concerning him: She despises you, laughs you to scorn, the virgin daughter Zion; Behind you she wags her head, daughter Jerusalem.

23.verse: Whom have you insulted and blasphemed, against whom have you raised your voice And lifted up your eyes on high? Against the Holy One of Israel!

24.verse: Through your servants you have insulted the Lord: You said, "With my many chariots I climbed the mountain heights, the recesses of Lebanon; I cut down its lofty cedars, its choice cypresses; I reached the remotest heights, its forest park.

25.verse: I dug wells and drank water in foreign lands; I dried up with the soles of my feet all the rivers of Egypt.

26.verse: Have you not heard? Long ago I prepared it, From days of old I planned it, now I have brought it to pass: That you should reduce fortified cities into heaps of ruins,

27.verse: While their inhabitants, shorn of power, are dismayed and ashamed, Becoming like the plants of the field, like the green growth, like the scorched grass on the housetops.

28.verse: I am aware whether you stand or sit; I know whether you come or go, and also your rage against me.

29.verse: Because of your rage against me and your fury which has reached my ears, I will put my hook in your nose and my bit in your mouth, and make you return the way you came.

30.verse: This shall be a sign for you: this year you shall eat the aftergrowth, next year, what grows of itself; But in the third year, sow and reap, plant vineyards and eat their fruit!

31.verse: The remaining survivors of the house of Judah shall again strike root below and bear fruit above.

32.verse: For out of Jerusalem shall come a remnant, and from Mount Zion, survivors. The zeal of the LORD of hosts shall do this.

33.verse: Therefore, thus says the LORD concerning the king of Assyria: He shall not reach this city, nor shoot an arrow at it, nor come before it with a shield, nor cast up siegeworks against it.

34.verse: He shall return by the same way he came, without entering the city, says the LORD.

35.verse: I will shield and save this city for my own sake, and for the sake of my servant David.

36.verse: The angel of the LORD went forth and struck down one hundred and eighty-five thousand in the Assyrian camp. Early the next morning, there they were, all the corpses of the dead.

37.verse: So Sennacherib, the king of Assyria, broke camp and went back home to Nineveh.

38.verse: When he was worshiping in the temple of his god Nisroch, his sons Adrammelech and Sharezer slew him with the sword and fled into the land of Ararat. His son Esarhaddon reigned in his stead.

annotations.1: [3] A proverbial expression. In the Bible the pangs of childbirth often typify extreme anguish; cf Isaiah 13:8; Jeremiah 6:24; Micah 4:9, 10. In this instance there is reference to the desperate situation of Hezekiah from which he was scarcely able to free himself.
annotations.2: [9] Tirhakah: may have been general of the Egyptian army in 701 B.C.; later he became king, one of the Ethiopian dynasty of Egyptian kings (c. 690-664 B.C.). Many consider that this account in Isaiah combines features of two originally distinct sieges of Jerusalem by Sennacherib
annotations.3: [16] In contrast to the empty boasting of the Assyrians, Hezekiah proclaims the Lord as God over all the kingdoms of the earth
annotations.4: [30] You: Hezekiah. A sign: it is difficult to know the nature of this sign. Either it is merely a proverbial expression to signify that prosperity follows adversity, or it indicates that after two years the normal conditions of life will be resumed
annotations.5: [36] The destruction of Sennacherib's army is also recorded by Herodotus, a Greek historian of the fifth century B.C. It was probably due to the bubonic plague, but the sacred author attributes it to its ultimate cause, God through his angel
annotations.6: [38] The violent death of Sennacherib (681 B.C.) is also mentioned in non-biblical sources. It occurred twenty years after his invasion of Judea

1.verse: All you who are thirsty, come to the water! You who have no money, come, receive grain and eat; Come, without paying and without cost, drink wine and milk!

2.verse: Why spend your money for what is not bread; your wages for what fails to satisfy? Heed me, and you shall eat well, you shall delight in rich fare.

3.verse: Come to me heedfully, listen, that you may have life. I will renew with you the everlasting covenant, the benefits assured to David.

4.verse: As I made him a witness to the peoples, a leader and commander of nations,

5.verse: So shall you summon a nation you knew not, and nations that knew you not shall run to you, Because of the LORD, your God, the Holy One of Israel, who has glorified you.

6.verse: Seek the LORD while he may be found, call him while he is near.

7.verse: Let the scoundrel forsake his way, and the wicked man his thoughts; Let him turn to the LORD for mercy; to our God, who is generous in forgiving.

8.verse: For my thoughts are not your thoughts, nor are your ways my ways, says the LORD.

9.verse: As high as the heavens are above the earth, so high are my ways above your ways and my thoughts above your thoughts.

10.verse: For just as from the heavens the rain and snow come down And do not return there till they have watered the earth, making it fertile and fruitful, Giving seed to him who sows and bread to him who eats,

11.verse: So shall my word be that goes forth from my mouth; It shall not return to me void, but shall do my will, achieving the end for which I sent it.

12.verse: Yes, in joy you shall depart, in peace you shall be brought back; Mountains and hills shall break out in song before you, and all the trees of the countryside shall clap their hands.

13.verse: In place of the thornbush, the cypress shall grow, instead of nettles, the myrtle. This shall be to the LORD'S renown, an everlasting imperishable sign.

annotations.1: [1-3] God's salvation is freely extended to his people and to all nations; through him will the benefits assured to David be renewed; cf Isaiah 12:3; John 7:37.
annotations.2: [13] Thornbush . . . nettles: suggestive of the desert and therefore symbolic of suffering and hardship; cypress, myrtle: suggestive of fertile land and therefore symbolic of joy and strength

1.verse: The vision which Isaiah, son of Amoz, had concerning Judah and Jerusalem in the days of Uzziah, Jotham, Ahaz and Hezekiah, kings of Judah.

2.verse: Hear, O heavens, and listen, O earth, for the LORD speaks: Sons have I raised and reared, but they have disowned me!

3.verse: An ox knows its owner, and an ass, its master's manger; But Israel does not know, my people has not understood.

4.verse: Ah! sinful nation, people laden with wickedness, evil race, corrupt children! They have forsaken the LORD, spurned the Holy One of Israel, apostatized.

5.verse: Where would you yet be struck, you that rebel again and again? The whole head is sick, the whole heart faint.

6.verse: From the sole of the foot to the head there is no sound spot: Wound and welt and gaping gash, not drained, or bandaged, or eased with salve.

7.verse: Your country is waste, your cities burnt with fire; Your land before your eyes strangers devour (a waste, like Sodom overthrown) -

8.verse: And daughter Zion is left like a hut in a vineyard, Like a shed in a melon patch, like a city blockaded.

9.verse: Unless the LORD of hosts had left us a scanty remnant, We had become as Sodom, we should be like Gomorrah.

10.verse: Hear the word of the LORD, princes of Sodom! Listen to the instruction of our God, people of Gomorrah!

11.verse: What care I for the number of your sacrifices? says the LORD. I have had enough of whole-burnt rams and fat of fatlings; In the blood of calves, lambs and goats I find no pleasure.

12.verse: When you come in to visit me, who asks these things of you?

13.verse: Trample my courts no more! Bring no more worthless offerings; your incense is loathsome to me. New moon and sabbath, calling of assemblies, octaves with wickedness: these I cannot bear.

14.verse: Your new moons and festivals I detest; they weigh me down, I tire of the load.

15.verse: When you spread out your hands, I close my eyes to you; Though you pray the more, I will not listen. Your hands are full of blood!

16.verse: Wash yourselves clean! Put away your misdeeds from before my eyes; cease doing evil;

17.verse: learn to do good. Make justice your aim: redress the wronged, hear the orphan's plea, defend the widow.

18.verse: Come now, let us set things right, says the LORD: Though your sins be like scarlet, they may become white as snow; Though they be crimson red, they may become white as wool.

19.verse: If you are willing, and obey, you shall eat the good things of the land;

20.verse: But if you refuse and resist, the sword shall consume you: for the mouth of the LORD has spoken!

21.verse: How has she turned adulteress, the faithful city, so upright! Justice used to lodge within her, but now, murderers.

22.verse: Your silver is turned to dross, your wine is mixed with water.

23.verse: Your princes are rebels and comrades of thieves; Each one of them loves a bribe and looks for gifts. The fatherless they defend not, and the widow's plea does not reach them.

24.verse: Now, therefore, says the Lord, the LORD of hosts, the Mighty One of Israel: Ah! I will take vengeance on my foes and fully repay my enemies!

25.verse: I will turn my hand against you, and refine your dross in the furnace, removing all your alloy.

26.verse: I will restore your judges as at first, and your counselors as in the beginning; After that you shall be called city of justice, faithful city.

27.verse: Zion shall be redeemed by judgment, and her repentant ones by justice.

28.verse: Rebels and sinners alike shall be crushed, those who desert the LORD shall be consumed.

29.verse: You shall be ashamed of the terebinths which you prized, and blush for the groves which you chose.

30.verse: You shall become like a tree with falling leaves, like a garden that has no water.

31.verse: The strong man shall turn to tow, and his work shall become a spark; Both shall burn together, and there shall be none to quench the flames.

annotations.1: [1] The title of the book: an editorial addition. Isaiah: meaning "the salvation of the LORD," or "The LORD is salvation." Amoz: not the minor prophet. Judah: the southern kingdom of the tribes of Judah and Benjamin. Uzziah: also called Azariah; cf 2 Kings 15:1; 2 Chron 26:1.
annotations.2: [3] Israel: not the northern kingdom, as in Isaiah 9:11 exclusively, which Isaiah usually calls "Ephraim" from the tribe bordering on the southern kingdom, but the entire chosen people, cf Isaiah 8:14
annotations.3: [4] Holy One of Israel: a title used frequently by Isaiah, rarely by other writers
annotations.4: [5-8] Sufferings inflicted upon God's people for their sins
annotations.5: [8] Daughter Zion: Jerusalem. Hut . . . shed: for the shelter of watchmen and laborers
annotations.6: [9] LORD of hosts: God, who is the Creator and Ruler of the heavenly armies of the angels, stars, etc. Remnant: St. Paul uses this text in Romans 9:29 where he speaks of God's saving mercy toward the Jews and Gentiles. Sodom . . . Gomorrah: cf Genesis 19
annotations.7: [11] The number of your sacrifices: however numerous, they are not acceptable without the right dispositions on the part of the worshipers
annotations.8: [13] Octaves with wickedness: the solemnity of the feasts marred by evil deeds
annotations.9: [15] Spread out your hands: in prayer
annotations.10: [21] A picture of Jerusalem, once so faithful to God. Apostasy from the covenant is often likened by the prophets to unfaithfulness to the marriage vow
annotations.11: [27] This verse is the key to the whole Book of Isaiah. Zion's defiant persistence in sin has demanded a divine judgment, by which her survivors will be cleansed and will return to God in justice; cf Isaiah 40:2
annotations.12: [29] Terebinths which you prized . . . groves which you chose: as popular shrines for idolatrous worship

1.verse: The Lord, the LORD of hosts, shall take away from Jerusalem and from Judah support and prop (all supplies of bread and water):

2.verse: Hero and warrior, judge and prophet, fortune-teller and elder,

3.verse: The captain of fifty and the nobleman, counselor, skilled magician, and expert charmer.

4.verse: I will make striplings their princes; the fickle shall govern them,

5.verse: And the people shall oppress one another, yes, every man his neighbor. The child shall be bold toward the elder, and the base toward the honorable.

6.verse: When a man seizes his brother in his father's house, saying, "You have clothes! Be our ruler, and take in hand this ruin!" -

7.verse: Then shall he answer in that day: "I will not undertake to cure this, when in my own house there is no bread or clothing! You shall not make me ruler of the people."

8.verse: Jerusalem is crumbling, Judah is falling; for their speech and their deeds are before the LORD, a provocation in the sight of his majesty.

9.verse: Their very look bears witness against them; their sin like Sodom they vaunt, They hide it not. Woe to them! they deal out evil to themselves.

10.verse: Happy the just, for it will be well with them, the fruit of their works they will eat.

11.verse: Woe to the wicked man! All goes ill, with the work of his hands he will be repaid.

12.verse: My people - a babe in arms will be their tyrant, and women will rule them! O my people, your leaders mislead, they destroy the paths you should follow.

13.verse: The LORD rises to accuse, standing to try his people.

14.verse: The Lord enters into judgment with his people's elders and princes: It is you who have devoured the vineyard; the loot wrested from the poor is in your houses.

15.verse: What do you mean by crushing my people, and grinding down the poor when they look to you? says the Lord, the GOD of hosts.

16.verse: The LORD said: Because the daughters of Zion are haughty, and walk with necks outstretched Ogling and mincing as they go, their anklets tinkling with every step,

17.verse: The Lord shall cover the scalps of Zion's daughters with scabs, and the LORD shall bare their heads.

18.verse: On that day the LORD will do away with the finery of the anklets, sunbursts, and crescents;

19.verse: the pendants, bracelets, and veils;

20.verse: the headdresses, bangles, cinctures, perfume boxes, and amulets;

21.verse: the signet rings, and the nose rings;

22.verse: the court dresses, wraps, cloaks, and purses;

23.verse: the mirrors, linen tunics, turbans, and shawls.

24.verse: Instead of perfume there will be stench, instead of the girdle, a rope, And for the coiffure, baldness; for the rich gown, a sackcloth skirt. Then, instead of beauty:

25.verse: Your men will fall by the sword, and your champions, in war;

26.verse: Her gates will lament and mourn, as the city sits desolate on the ground.

annotations.1: [1-12] Anarchy will reign in Jerusalem and Judah. In the prevailing desperation, even the most unworthy and the least qualified will be sought as rulers.
annotations.2: [17] Bare their heads: a mark of social disgrace; cf Numbers 5:18
annotations.3: [21] Nose rings: of gold, a feminine ornament in the East; cf note on Genesis 24:22

1.verse: Thus says the LORD: The heavens are my throne, the earth is my footstool. What kind of house can you build for me; what is to be my resting place?

2.verse: My hand made all these things when all of them came to be, says the LORD. This is the one whom I approve: the lowly and afflicted man who trembles at my word.

3.verse: Merely slaughtering an ox is like slaying a man; sacrificing a lamb, like breaking a dog's neck; Bringing a cereal offering, like offering swine's blood; burning incense, like paying homage to an idol. Since these have chosen their own ways and taken pleasure in their own abominations,

4.verse: I in turn will choose ruthless treatment for them and bring upon them what they fear. Because, when I called, no one answered, when I spoke, no one listened; Because they did what was evil in my sight, and chose what gave me displeasure,

5.verse: Hear the word of the LORD, you who tremble at his word: Your brethren who, because of my name, hate and reject you, say, "Let the LORD show his glory that we may see your joy"; but they shall be put to shame.

6.verse: A sound of roaring from the city, a sound from the temple, The sound of the LORD repaying his enemies their deserts!

7.verse: Before she comes to labor, she gives birth; Before the pains come upon her, she safely delivers a male child.

8.verse: Who ever heard of such a thing, or saw the like? Can a country be brought forth in one day, or a nation be born in a single moment? Yet Zion is scarcely in labor when she gives birth to her children.

9.verse: Shall I bring a mother to the point of birth, and yet not let her child be born? says the LORD; Or shall I who allow her to conceive, yet close her womb? says your God.

10.verse: Rejoice with Jerusalem and be glad because of her, all you who love her; Exult, exult with her, all you who were mourning over her!

11.verse: Oh, that you may suck fully of the milk of her comfort, That you may nurse with delight at her abundant breasts!

12.verse: For thus says the LORD: Lo, I will spread prosperity over her like a river, and the wealth of the nations like an overflowing torrent. As nurslings, you shall be carried in her arms, and fondled in her lap;

13.verse: As a mother comforts her son, so will I comfort you; in Jerusalem you shall find your comfort.

14.verse: When you see this, your heart shall rejoice, and your bodies flourish like the grass; The LORD'S power shall be known to his servants, but to his enemies, his wrath.

15.verse: Lo, the LORD shall come in fire, his chariots like the whirlwind, To wreak his wrath with burning heat and his punishment with fiery flames.

16.verse: For the LORD shall judge all mankind by fire and sword. and many shall be slain by the LORD.

17.verse: They who sanctify and purify themselves to go to the groves, as followers of one who stands within, they who eat swine's flesh, loathsome things and mice, shall all perish with their deeds and their thoughts, says the LORD.

18.verse: I come to gather nations of every language; they shall come and see my glory.

19.verse: I will set a sign among them; from them I will send fugitives to the nations: to Tarshish, Put and Lud, Mosoch, Tubal and Javan, to the distant coastlands that have never heard of my fame, or seen my glory; and they shall proclaim my glory among the nations.

20.verse: They shall bring all your brethren from all the nations as an offering to the LORD, on horses and in chariots, in carts, upon mules and dromedaries, to Jerusalem, my holy mountain, says the LORD, just as the Israelites bring their offering to the house of the LORD in clean vessels.

21.verse: Some of these I will take as priests and Levites, says the LORD.

22.verse: As the new heavens and the new earth which I will make Shall endure before me, says the LORD, so shall your race and your name endure.

23.verse: From one new moon to another, and from one sabbath to another, All mankind shall come to worship before me, says the LORD.

24.verse: They shall go out and see the corpses of the men who rebelled against me; Their worm shall not die, nor their fire be extinguished; and they shall be abhorrent to all mankind.

annotations.1: [4-5] Worship which is merely external is as evil as though it were idolatry.
annotations.2: [7-9] The absence of labor in Zion's childbearing is a symbol of the joyful begetting of the new people of God
annotations.3: [18-21] God summons the neighboring nations to Zion and from among them will send some to far distant lands to proclaim his glory. All your brethren: Jews in exile
annotations.4: [24] God's enemies lie dead outside the walls of the New Jerusalem; just as in the past, corpses, filth and refuse lay in the Valley of Hinnom outside the city, where huge fires were constantly burning; cf Joshua 15:8; 2 Chron 28:3; Mark 9:45-48

1.verse: The desert and the parched land will exult; the steppe will rejoice and bloom.

2.verse: They will bloom with abundant flowers, and rejoice with joyful song. The glory of Lebanon will be given to them, the splendor of Carmel and Sharon; They will see the glory of the LORD, the splendor of our God.

3.verse: Strengthen the hands that are feeble, make firm the knees that are weak,

4.verse: Say to those whose hearts are frightened: Be strong, fear not! Here is your God, he comes with vindication; With divine recompense he comes to save you.

5.verse: Then will the eyes of the blind be opened, the ears of the deaf be cleared;

6.verse: Then will the lame leap like a stag, then the tongue of the dumb will sing. Streams will burst forth in the desert, and rivers in the steppe.

7.verse: The burning sands will become pools, and the thirsty ground, springs of water; The abode where jackals lurk will be a marsh for the reed and papyrus.

8.verse: A highway will be there, called the holy way; No one unclean may pass over it, nor fools go astray on it.

9.verse: No lion will be there, nor beast of prey go up to be met upon it. It is for those with a journey to make, and on it the redeemed will walk.

10.verse: Those whom the LORD has ransomed will return and enter Zion singing, crowned with everlasting joy; They will meet with joy and gladness, sorrow and mourning will flee.

annotations.1: [1-10] Similar to the description of the return from the exile, as found in Isaiah 40-55.

1.verse: Woe to those who enact unjust statutes and who write oppressive decrees,

2.verse: Depriving the needy of judgment and robbing my people's poor of their rights, Making widows their plunder, and orphans their prey!

3.verse: What will you do on the day of punishment, when ruin comes from afar? To whom will you flee for help? Where will you leave your wealth,

4.verse: Lest it sink beneath the captive or fall beneath the slain? For all this, his wrath is not turned back, his hand is still outstretched!

5.verse: Woe to Assyria! My rod in anger, my staff in wrath.

6.verse: Against an impious nation I send him, and against a people under my wrath I order him To seize plunder, carry off loot, and tread them down like the mud of the streets.

7.verse: But this is not what he intends, nor does he have this in mind; Rather, it is in his heart to destroy, to make an end of nations not a few.

8.verse: "Are not my commanders all kings?" he says,

9.verse: "Is not Calno like Carchemish, Or Hamath like Arpad, or Samaria like Damascus?

10.verse: Just as my hand reached out to idolatrous kingdoms that had more images than Jerusalem and Samaria,

11.verse: Just as I treated Samaria and her idols, shall I not do to Jerusalem and her graven images?"

12.verse: (But when the LORD has brought to an end all his work on Mount Zion and in Jerusalem, I will punish the utterance of the king of Assyria's proud heart,

13.verse: and the boastfulness of his haughty eyes. For he says:) "By my own power I have done it, and by my wisdom, for I am shrewd. I have moved the boundaries of peoples, their treasures I have pillaged, and, like a giant, I have put down the enthroned.

14.verse: My hand has seized like a nest the riches of nations; As one takes eggs left alone, so I took in all the earth; No one fluttered a wing, or opened a mouth, or chirped!"

15.verse: Will the axe boast against him who hews with it? Will the saw exalt itself above him who wields it? As if a rod could sway him who lifts it, or a staff him who is not wood!

16.verse: Therefore the Lord, the LORD of hosts, will send among his fat ones leanness, And instead of his glory there will be kindling like the kindling of fire.

17.verse: The Light of Israel will become a fire, Israel's Holy One a flame, That burns and consumes his briers and his thorns in a single day.

18.verse: His splendid forests and orchards will be consumed, soul and body;

19.verse: And the remnant of the trees in his forest will be so few, Like poles set up for signals, that any boy can record them.

20.verse: On that day The remnant of Israel, the survivors of the house of Jacob, will no more lean upon him who struck them; But they lean upon the LORD, the Holy One of Israel, in truth.

21.verse: A remnant will return, the remnant of Jacob, to the mighty God.

22.verse: For though your people, O Israel, were like the sand of the sea, Only a remnant of them will return; their destruction is decreed as overwhelming justice demands.

23.verse: Yes, the destruction he has decreed, the Lord, the GOD of hosts, will carry out within the whole land.

24.verse: Therefore thus says the Lord, the GOD of hosts: O my people, who dwell in Zion, do not fear the Assyrian, though he strikes you with a rod, and raises his staff against you.

25.verse: For only a brief moment more, and my anger shall be over; but them I will destroy in wrath.

26.verse: Then the LORD of hosts will raise against them a scourge such as struck Midian at the rock of Oreb; and he will raise his staff over the sea as he did against Egypt.

27.verse: On that day, His burden shall be taken from your shoulder, and his yoke shattered from your neck. He has come up from the direction of Rimmon,

28.verse: he has reached Aiath, passed through Migron, at Michmash his supplies are stored.

29.verse: They cross the ravine: "We will spend the night at Geba." Ramah is in terror, Gibeah of Saul has fled.

30.verse: Cry and shriek, O daughter of Gallim! Hearken, Laishah! Answer her, Anathoth!

31.verse: Madmenah is in flight, the inhabitants of Gebim seek refuge.

32.verse: Even today he will halt at Nob, he will shake his fist at the mount of daughter Zion, the hill of Jerusalem!

33.verse: Behold, the Lord, the LORD of hosts, lops off the boughs with terrible violence; The tall of stature are felled, and the lofty ones brought low;

34.verse: The forest thickets are felled with the axe, and Lebanon in its splendor falls.

annotations.1: [6-7] Impious nation: Israel. It was God's intention to use Assyria merely to punish, not to destroy, his people.
annotations.2: [9] Calno . . . Damascus: cities captured by the Assyrians
annotations.3: [16] His fat ones: the strong men of the king of Assyria
annotations.4: [21] A remnant will return: in Hebrew, shear-jashub, an allusion to the name of Isaiah's son, Shear-jashub; cf Isaiah 7:3
annotations.5: [27-32] A poetic description of the progress of the Assyrian army, advancing from the north through Judah to the gates of Jerusalem
annotations.6: [32-34] Just when the enemy is about to capture Jerusalem, God intervenes and destroys the hostile army

1.verse: Oracle on Damascus: Lo, Damascus shall cease to be a city and become a ruin;

2.verse: Her cities shall be forever abandoned, given over to flocks to lie in undisturbed.

3.verse: The fortress shall be lost to Ephraim and the kingdom to Damascus; The remnant of Aram shall have the same glory as the Israelites, says the LORD of hosts.

4.verse: On that day The glory of Jacob shall fade, and his full body grow thin,

5.verse: Like the reaper's mere armful of stalks when he gathers the standing grain; Or as when one gleans the ears in the Valley of Rephaim.

6.verse: Only a scattering of grapes shall be left! As when an olive tree has been beaten, Two or three olives remain at the very top, four or five on its fruitful branches, says the LORD, the God of Israel.

7.verse: On that day man shall look to his maker, his eyes turned toward the Holy One of Israel.

8.verse: He shall not look to the altars, his handiwork, nor shall he regard what his fingers have made: the sacred poles or the incense stands.

9.verse: On that day his strong cities shall be like those abandoned by the Hivites and Amorites When faced with the children of Israel: they shall be laid waste.

10.verse: For you have forgotten God, your savior, and remembered not the Rock, your strength. Therefore, though you plant your pagan plants and set out your foreign vine slips,

11.verse: Though you make them grow the day you plant them and make your sprouts blossom on the next morning, The harvest shall disappear on the day of the grievous blow, the incurable blight.

12.verse: Ah! the roaring of many peoples that roar like the roar of the seas! The surging of nations that surge like the surging of mighty waves!

13.verse: But God shall rebuke them, and they shall flee far away; Windswept, like chaff on the mountains, like tumbleweed in a storm.

14.verse: In the evening, they spread terror, before morning, they are gone! Such is the portion of those who despoil us, the lot of those who plunder us.

annotations.1: [1] Damascus: capital of Syria, destroyed in 732 B.C.
annotations.2: [3] Ephraim: Israel, leagued with Syria against Assyria and Judah; destroyed in 721 B.C. Aram: Syria
annotations.3: [5] Valley of Rephaim: a fertile plain to the southwest of Jerusalem; cf Joshua 15:8; 2 Sam 5:18
annotations.4: [6] Olives not easily picked by hand were knocked from the tree by means of a long stick; cf Isaiah 24:13
annotations.5: [8] Sacred poles: see note on Exodus 34:13. Incense stands: small altars on which incense was burned in idolatrous worship; cf Isaiah 27:9; Lev 26:30
annotations.6: [10] Pagan plants: literally "plants of delights," understood by some as planted in honor of the god of fertility
annotations.7: [12-13] Many peoples: the hordes that accompanied the invading Assyrians, whom God repels just as he vanquished the primeval waters of chaos; see notes on Job 3:8; 7:12; Psalm 89:10

1.verse: Seven women will take hold of one man on that day, saying: "We will eat our own food and wear our own clothing; Only let your name be given us, put an end to our disgrace!"

2.verse: On that day, The branch of the LORD will be luster and glory, and the fruit of the earth will be honor and splendor for the survivors of Israel.

3.verse: He who remains in Zion and he that is left in Jerusalem Will be called holy: every one marked down for life in Jerusalem.

4.verse: When the Lord washes away the filth of the daughters of Zion, And purges Jerusalem's blood from her midst with a blast of searing judgment,

5.verse: Then will the LORD create, over the whole site of Mount Zion and over her place of assembly, A smoking cloud by day and a light of flaming fire by night.

6.verse: For over all, his glory will be shelter and protection: shade from the parching heat of day, refuge and cover from storm and rain.

annotations.1: [1] Seven women . . . one man: the disproportion of the sexes due to war leaves the female population almost without male partners. The women are eager to marry, not for support, but to avoid the disgrace of being childless.
annotations.2: [2] Branch of the LORD: divine blessings in general, which later culminated in the Messiah; cf Jeremiah 23:5; Zechariah 3:8; 6:12
annotations.3: [3] Marked down for life: in God's list of his elect; cf Exodus 32:32

1.verse: Hear me, O coastlands, listen, O distant peoples. The LORD called me from birth, from my mother's womb he gave me my name.

2.verse: He made of me a sharp-edged sword and concealed me in the shadow of his arm. He made me a polished arrow, in his quiver he hid me.

3.verse: You are my servant, he said to me, Israel, through whom I show my glory.

4.verse: Though I thought I had toiled in vain, and for nothing, uselessly, spent my strength, Yet my reward is with the LORD, my recompense is with my God.

5.verse: For now the LORD has spoken who formed me as his servant from the womb, That Jacob may be brought back to him and Israel gathered to him; And I am made glorious in the sight of the LORD, and my God is now my strength!

6.verse: It is too little, he says, for you to be my servant, to raise up the tribes of Jacob, and restore the survivors of Israel; I will make you a light to the nations, that my salvation may reach to the ends of the earth.

7.verse: Thus says the LORD, the redeemer and the Holy One of Israel, To the one despised, whom the nations abhor, the slave of rulers: When kings see you, they shall stand up, and princes shall prostrate themselves Because of the LORD who is faithful, the Holy One of Israel who has chosen you.

8.verse: Thus says the LORD: In a time of favor I answer you, on the day of salvation I help you, To restore the land and allot the desolate heritages,

9.verse: Saying to the prisoners: Come out! To those in darkness: Show yourselves! Along the ways they shall find pasture, on every bare height shall their pastures be.

10.verse: They shall not hunger or thirst, nor shall the scorching wind or the sun strike them; For he who pities them leads them and guides them beside springs of water.

11.verse: I will cut a road through all my mountains, and make my highways level.

12.verse: See, some shall come from afar, others from the north and the west, and some from the land of Syene.

13.verse: Sing out, O heavens, and rejoice, O earth, break forth into song, you mountains. For the LORD comforts his people and shows mercy to his afflicted.

14.verse: But Zion said, "The LORD has forsaken me; my Lord has forgotten me."

15.verse: Can a mother forget her infant, be without tenderness for the child of her womb? Even should she forget, I will never forget you.

16.verse: See, upon the palms of my hands I have written your name; your walls are ever before me.

17.verse: Your rebuilders make haste, as those who tore you down and laid you waste go forth from you;

18.verse: Look about and see, they are all gathering and coming to you. As I live, says the LORD, you shall be arrayed with them all as with adornments, like a bride you shall fasten them on you.

19.verse: Though you were waste and desolate, a land of ruins, Now you shall be too small for your inhabitants, while those who swallowed you up will be far away.

20.verse: The children whom you had lost shall yet say to you, "This place is too small for me, make room for me to live in."

21.verse: You shall ask yourself: "Who has borne me these? I was bereft and barren (exiled and repudiated); who has reared them? I was left all alone; where then do these come from?"

22.verse: Thus says the Lord GOD: See, I will lift up my hand to the nations, and raise my signal to the peoples; They shall bring your sons in their arms, and your daughters shall be carried on their shoulders.

23.verse: Kings shall be your foster fathers, their princesses your nurses; Bowing to the ground, they shall worship you and lick the dust at your feet. Then you shall know that I am the LORD, and those who hope in me shall never be disappointed.

24.verse: Thus says the LORD: Can booty be taken from a warrior? or captives be rescued from a tyrant?

25.verse: Yes, captives can be taken from a warrior, and booty be rescued from a tyrant; Those who oppose you I will oppose, and your sons I will save.

26.verse: I will make your oppressors eat their own flesh, and they shall be drunk with their own blood as with the juice of the grape. All mankind shall know that I, the LORD, am your savior, your redeemer, the Mighty One of Jacob.

annotations.1: [1-7] The second of the four "Servant-of-the-Lord" oracles
annotations.2: [1] Gave me my name: designated me for a special office (cf Jeremiah 1:5), or perhaps, made me renowned (cf Psalm 45:18).
annotations.3: [2] The Servant was made ready and fit for the preaching of God's word
annotations.4: [3] Israel: the Servant is identified with the people of Israel as their ideal representative; however, since Isaiah 49:5, 6 seem to distinguish the Servant from Israel, some regard the word Israel here as a gloss
annotations.5: [6] The Servant's vocation will be not only the restoration of Israel but the conversion of the world; cf Luke 2:32
annotations.6: [12] Syene: now called Aswan, at the first cataract of the Nile in southern Egypt
annotations.7: [16] Upon the palms . . . name: for continual remembrance; cf Exodus 13:9, 16; Deut 6:6-9

1.verse: An oracle concerning Babylon; a vision of Isaiah, son of Amoz.

2.verse: Upon the bare mountains set up a signal; cry out to them, Wave for them to enter the gates of the volunteers.

3.verse: I have commanded my dedicated soldiers, I have summoned my warriors, eager and bold to carry out my anger.

4.verse: Listen! the rumble on the mountains: that of an immense throng! Listen! the noise of kingdoms, nations assembled! The LORD of hosts is mustering an army for battle.

5.verse: They come from a far-off country, and from the end of the heavens, The LORD and the instruments of his wrath, to destroy all the land.

6.verse: Howl, for the day of the LORD is near; as destruction from the Almighty it comes.

7.verse: Therefore all hands fall helpless, the bows of the young men fall from their hands. Every man's heart melts

8.verse: in terror. Pangs and sorrows take hold of them, like a woman in labor they writhe; They look aghast at each other, their faces aflame.

9.verse: Lo, the day of the LORD comes, cruel, with wrath and burning anger; To lay waste the land and destroy the sinners within it!

10.verse: The stars and constellations of the heavens send forth no light; The sun is dark when it rises, and the light of the moon does not shine.

11.verse: Thus I will punish the world for its evil and the wicked for their guilt. I will put an end to the pride of the arrogant, the insolence of tyrants I will humble.

12.verse: I will make mortals more rare than pure gold, men, than gold of Ophir.

13.verse: For this I will make the heavens tremble and the earth shall be shaken from its place, At the wrath of the LORD of hosts on the day of his burning anger.

14.verse: Like a hunted gazelle, or a flock that no one gathers, Every man shall turn to his kindred and flee to his own land.

15.verse: Everyone who is caught shall be run through; to a man, they shall fall by the sword.

16.verse: Their infants shall be dashed to pieces in their sight; their houses shall be plundered and their wives ravished.

17.verse: I am stirring up against them the Medes, who think nothing of silver and take no delight in gold.

18.verse: The fruit of the womb they shall not spare, nor shall they have eyes of pity for children.

19.verse: And Babylon, the jewel of kingdoms, the glory and pride of the Chaldeans, Shall be overthrown by God like Sodom and like Gomorrah.

20.verse: She shall never be inhabited, nor dwelt in, from age to age; The Arab shall not pitch his tent there, nor shepherds couch their flocks.

21.verse: But wildcats shall rest there and owls shall fill the houses; There ostriches shall dwell, and satyrs shall dance.

22.verse: Desert beasts shall howl in her castles, and jackals in her luxurious palaces. Her time is near at hand and her days shall not be prolonged.

annotations.1: [2] To them: the Medes ( Isaiah 13:17) and Persians, who would destroy Babylon. Gates of the volunteers: the mustering places of Babylon's enemies for war against her.
annotations.2: [3] Dedicated soldiers: in the sense that they will wage a "holy war" and carry out God's plan
annotations.3: [6-8] Day of the LORD: described often in prophetical writings, it generally signified the coming of the Lord in power and majesty to destroy his enemies and inaugurate his kingdom. Here it refers to the overthrow of Babylon. The figures used convey the idea of horror and destruction. Read together Isaiah 13:6-8, 14-16
annotations.4: [12] Ophir: cf note to Psalm 45:9
annotations.5: [21] Satyrs: in the popular mind, demons of goatlike form dwelling in ruins, symbols of immorality; cf Lev 17:7

1.verse: In the year the general sent by Sargon, king of Assyria, fought against Ashdod and captured it,

2.verse: the LORD gave a warning through Isaiah, the son of Amoz: Go and take off the sackcloth from your waist, and remove the sandals from your feet. This he did, walking naked and barefoot.

3.verse: Then the LORD said: Just as my servant Isaiah has gone naked and barefoot for three years as a sign and portent against Egypt and Ethiopia,

4.verse: so shall the king of Assyria lead away captives from Egypt, and exiles from Ethiopia, young and old, naked and barefoot, with buttocks uncovered (the shame of Egypt).

5.verse: They shall be dismayed and ashamed because of Ethiopia, their hope, and because of Egypt, their boast.

6.verse: The inhabitants of this coastland shall say on that day, "Look at our hope! We have fled here for help and deliverance from the king of Assyria; where can we flee now?"

annotations.1: [2-6] The symbolic act of the prophet conveyed the idea that Assyria would lead captive the Egyptians and Ethiopians. The Judeans and their allies would then realize the folly of having trusted in them.

1.verse: But now, thus says the LORD, who created you, O Jacob, and formed you, O Israel: Fear not, for I have redeemed you; I have called you by name: you are mine.

2.verse: When you pass through the water, I will be with you; in the rivers you shall not drown. When you walk through fire, you shall not be burned; the flames shall not consume you.

3.verse: For I am the LORD, your God, the Holy One of Israel, your savior. I give Egypt as your ransom, Ethiopia and Seba in return for you.

4.verse: Because you are precious in my eyes and glorious, and because I love you, I give men in return for you and peoples in exchange for your life.

5.verse: Fear not, for I am with you; from the east I will bring back your descendants, from the west I will gather you.

6.verse: I will say to the north: Give them up! and to the south: Hold not back! Bring back my sons from afar, and my daughters from the ends of the earth:

7.verse: Everyone who is named as mine, whom I created for my glory, whom I formed and made.

8.verse: Lead out the people who are blind though they have eyes, who are deaf though they have ears.

9.verse: Let all the nations gather together, let the peoples assemble! Who among them could have revealed this, or foretold to us the earlier things? Let them produce witnesses to prove themselves right, that one may hear and say, "It is true!"

10.verse: You are my witnesses, says the LORD, my servants whom I have chosen To know and believe in me and understand that it is I. Before me no god was formed, and after me there shall be none.

11.verse: It is I, I the LORD; there is no savior but me.

12.verse: It is I who foretold, I who saved; I made it known, not any strange god among you; You are my witnesses, says the LORD. I am God,

13.verse: yes, from eternity I am He; There is none who can deliver from my hand: who can countermand what I do?

14.verse: Thus says the LORD, your redeemer, the Holy One of Israel: For your sakes I send to Babylon; I will lower all the bars, and the Chaldeans shall cry out in lamentation.

15.verse: I am the LORD, your Holy One, the creator of Israel, your King.

16.verse: Thus says the LORD, who opens a way in the sea and a path in the mighty waters,

17.verse: Who leads out chariots and horsemen, a powerful army, Till they lie prostrate together, never to rise, snuffed out and quenched like a wick.

18.verse: Remember not the events of the past, the things of long ago consider not;

19.verse: See, I am doing something new! Now it springs forth, do you not perceive it? In the desert I make a way, in the wasteland, rivers.

20.verse: Wild beasts honor me, jackals and ostriches, For I put water in the desert and rivers in the wasteland for my chosen people to drink,

21.verse: The people whom I formed for myself, that they might announce my praise.

22.verse: Yet you did not call upon me, O Jacob, for you grew weary of me, O Israel.

23.verse: You did not bring me sheep for your holocausts, nor honor me with your sacrifices. I did not exact from you the service of offerings, nor weary you for frankincense.

24.verse: You did not buy me sweet cane for money, nor fill me with the fat of your sacrifices; Instead, you burdened me with your sins, and wearied me with your crimes.

25.verse: It is I, I, who wipe out, for my own sake, your offenses; your sins I remember no more.

26.verse: Would you have me remember, have us come to trial? Speak up, prove your innocence!

27.verse: Your first father sinned; your spokesmen rebelled against me

28.verse: Till I repudiated the holy gates, put Jacob under the ban, and exposed Israel to scorn.

annotations.1: [3-4] Egypt . . . Ethiopia and Seba: countries which God permitted the Persians to conquer in return for having given Israel its freedom.
annotations.2: [9] Only God can know and predict future events; cf Isaiah 41:1-5, 21-29
annotations.3: [14-17] The destruction of Babylon
annotations.4: [18] No need to think solely of the past wonders of the exodus from Egypt; equally great is the exodus from Babylon
annotations.5: [22-28] The reason for the liberation of the Israelites is not their fidelity but rather God's mercy
annotations.6: [24] Sweet cane: a fragrant substance used in making incense and the sacred anointing oil; cf Exodus 30:23; Jeremiah 6:20
annotations.7: [27] First father: Adam or Jacob, or collectively "early ancestors." Spokesmen: leaders, priests, prophets

1.verse: But a shoot shall sprout from the stump of Jesse, and from his roots a bud shall blossom.

2.verse: The spirit of the LORD shall rest upon him: a spirit of wisdom and of understanding, A spirit of counsel and of strength, a spirit of knowledge and of fear of the LORD,

3.verse: and his delight shall be the fear of the LORD. Not by appearance shall he judge, nor by hearsay shall he decide,

4.verse: But he shall judge the poor with justice, and decide aright for the land's afflicted. He shall strike the ruthless with the rod of his mouth, and with the breath of his lips he shall slay the wicked.

5.verse: Justice shall be the band around his waist, and faithfulness a belt upon his hips.

6.verse: Then the wolf shall be a guest of the lamb, and the leopard shall lie down with the kid; The calf and the young lion shall browse together, with a little child to guide them.

7.verse: The cow and the bear shall be neighbors, together their young shall rest; the lion shall eat hay like the ox.

8.verse: The baby shall play by the cobra's den, and the child lay his hand on the adder's lair.

9.verse: There shall be no harm or ruin on all my holy mountain; for the earth shall be filled with knowledge of the LORD, as water covers the sea.

10.verse: On that day, The root of Jesse, set up as a signal for the nations, The Gentiles shall seek out, for his dwelling shall be glorious.

11.verse: On that day, The Lord shall again take it in hand to reclaim the remnant of his people that is left from Assyria and Egypt, Pathros, Ethiopia, and Elam, Shinar, Hamath, and the isles of the sea.

12.verse: He shall raise a signal to the nations and gather the outcasts of Israel; The dispersed of Judah he shall assemble from the four corners of the earth.

13.verse: The envy of Ephraim shall pass away, and the rivalry of Judah be removed; Ephraim shall not be jealous of Judah, and Judah shall not be hostile to Ephraim;

14.verse: But they shall swoop down on the foothills of the Philistines to the west, together they shall plunder the Kedemites; Edom and Moab shall be their possessions, and the Ammonites their subjects.

15.verse: The LORD shall dry up the tongue of the Sea of Egypt, and wave his hand over the Euphrates in his fierce anger And shatter it into seven streamlets, so that it can be crossed in sandals.

16.verse: There shall be a highway for the remnant of his people that is left from Assyria, As there was for Israel when he came up from the land of Egypt.

annotations.1: [1] Jesse: David's father. Shoot . . . stump: after the Babylonian Exile only a stump of the Davidic dynasty will remain; from it will arise the new shoot, the messianic King.
annotations.2: [2-3] The source of the traditional names of the gifts of the Holy Spirit. The Septuagint and the Vulgate read "piety" for fear of the LORD in its first occurence, thus listing seven gifts
annotations.3: [6-9] This picture of the idyllic harmony of paradise is a dramatic symbol of the universal peace and justice of messianic times
annotations.4: [11] Pathros . . . sea: where God's people lived in exile. Pathros: upper Egypt. Elam: east of Babylonia. Shinar: Babylonia. Hamath: on the Orontes River in Syria. Isles: or coastlands, in the Mediterranean
annotations.5: [14] Kedemites: tribes in the Arabian Desert
