1.verse: Oracle on Tyre: Wail, O ships of Tarshish, for your port is destroyed; From the land of the Kittim the news reaches them.

2.verse: Silence! you who dwell on the coast, you merchants of Sidon, Whose messengers crossed the sea

3.verse: over the deep waters. The grain of Shihor, the harvest of the Nile, was her revenue, and she the merchant among nations.

4.verse: Shame, O Sidon, fortress on the sea, for the sea has spoken: "I have not been in labor, nor given birth, nor raised young men, nor reared virgins."

5.verse: When it is heard in Egypt they shall be in anguish at the news of Tyre.

6.verse: Pass over to Tarshish, wailing, you who dwell on the coast!

7.verse: Is this your wanton city, whose origin is from old, Whose feet have taken her to dwell in distant lands?

8.verse: Who has planned such a thing against Tyre, the bestower of crowns, Whose merchants are princes, whose traders are the earth's honored men?

9.verse: The LORD of hosts has planned it, to disgrace all pride of majesty, to degrade all the earth's honored men.

10.verse: Cross to your own land, O ship of Tarshish; the harbor is no more.

11.verse: His hand he stretches out over the sea, he shakes kingdoms; The LORD has ordered the destruction of Canaan's strongholds.

12.verse: You shall exult no more, he says, you who are now oppressed, virgin daughter Sidon. Arise, pass over to the Kittim, even there you shall find no rest.

13.verse: (This people is the land of the Chaldeans, not Assyria.) She whom the impious founded, setting up towers for her, Has had her castles destroyed, and has been turned into a ruin.

14.verse: Lament, O ships of Tarshish, for your haven is destroyed.

15.verse: On that day, Tyre shall be forgotten for seventy years. With the days of another king, at the end of seventy years, it shall be for Tyre as in the song about the harlot:

16.verse: Take a harp, go about the city, O forgotten harlot; Pluck the strings skillfully, sing many songs, that they may remember you.

17.verse: At the end of the seventy years the LORD shall visit Tyre. She shall return to her hire and deal with all the world's kingdoms on the face of the earth.

18.verse: But her merchandise and her hire shall be sacred to the LORD. It shall not be stored up or laid away, but from her merchandise those who dwell before the LORD shall eat their fill and clothe themselves in choice attire.

annotations.1: [1-4,12-14] These verses refer to Sidon, Isaiah 23:5-11 to Tyre
annotations.2: [1] Kittim: Cyprus.
annotations.3: [3] Shihor: a synonym for the Nile
annotations.4: [4] The sea: brings to distant coasts the news that Sidon must disown her children; her people are dispersed
annotations.5: [11] Canaan's strongholds: the fortresses of Phoenicia
annotations.6: [13] The gloss here identifies she whom the impious founded with the land of the Chaldeans
annotations.7: [15] Seventy years: a conventional period of time indicating simply a long disaster; cf Jeremiah 25:11; 29:10

1.verse: Woe to the rebellious children, says the LORD, Who carry out plans that are not mine, who weave webs that are not inspired by me, adding sin upon sin.

2.verse: They go down to Egypt, but my counsel they do not seek. They find their strength in Pharaoh's protection and take refuge in Egypt's shadow;

3.verse: Pharaoh's protection shall be your shame, and refuge in Egypt's shadow your disgrace.

4.verse: When their princes are at Zoan and their messengers reach Hanes,

5.verse: All shall be ashamed of a people that gain them nothing, Neither help nor benefit, but only shame and reproach.

6.verse: (Oracle on the Beasts of the Negeb) Through the distressed and troubled land of the lioness and roaring lion, of the viper and flying saraph, They carry their riches on the backs of asses and their treasures on the humps of camels To a people good for nothing,

7.verse: to Egypt whose help is futile and vain. Therefore I call her "Rahab quelled."

8.verse: Now come, write it on a tablet they can keep, inscribe it in a record; That it may be in future days an eternal witness:

9.verse: This is a rebellious people, deceitful children, Children who refuse to obey the law of the LORD.

10.verse: They say to the seers, "Have no visions"; to the prophets, "Do not descry for us what is right; speak flatteries to us, conjure up illusions.

11.verse: Out of the way! Out of our path! Let us hear no more of the Holy One of Israel."

12.verse: Therefore, thus says the Holy One of Israel: Because you reject this word, And put your trust in what is crooked and devious, and depend on it,

13.verse: This guilt of yours shall be like a descending rift Bulging out in a high wall whose crash comes suddenly, in an instant.

14.verse: It crashes like a potter's jar smashed beyond rescue, And among its fragments cannot be found a sherd to scoop fire from the hearth or dip water from the cistern.

15.verse: For thus said the Lord GOD, the Holy One of Israel: By waiting and by calm you shall be saved, in quiet and in trust your strength lies. But this you did not wish.

16.verse: "No," you said, "Upon horses we will flee." - Very well, flee! "Upon swift steeds we will ride." - Not so swift as your pursuers.

17.verse: A thousand shall tremble at the threat of one; if five threaten you, you shall flee, Until you are left like a flagstaff on the mountaintop, like a flag on the hill.

18.verse: Yet the LORD is waiting to show you favor, and he rises to pity you; For the LORD is a God of justice: blessed are all who wait for him!

19.verse: O people of Zion, who dwell in Jerusalem, no more will you weep; He will be gracious to you when you cry out, as soon as he hears he will answer you.

20.verse: The Lord will give you the bread you need and the water for which you thirst. No longer will your Teacher hide himself, but with your own eyes you shall see your Teacher,

21.verse: While from behind, a voice shall sound in your ears: "This is the way; walk in it," when you would turn to the right or to the left.

22.verse: And you shall consider unclean your silver-plated idols and your gold-covered images; You shall throw them away like filthy rags to which you say, "Begone!"

23.verse: He will give rain for the seed that you sow in the ground, And the wheat that the soil produces will be rich and abundant. On that day your cattle will graze in spacious meadows;

24.verse: The oxen and the asses that till the ground will eat silage tossed to them with shovel and pitchfork.

25.verse: Upon every high mountain and lofty hill there will be streams of running water. On the day of the great slaughter, when the towers fall,

26.verse: The light of the moon will be like that of the sun and the light of the sun will be seven times greater (like the light of seven days). On the day the LORD binds up the wounds of his people, he will heal the bruises left by his blows.

27.verse: See the name of the LORD coming from afar in burning wrath, with lowering clouds! His lips are filled with fury, his tongue is like a consuming fire;

28.verse: His breath, like a flood in a ravine that reaches suddenly to the neck, Will winnow the nations with a destructive winnowing, and with repeated winnowings will he battle against them (and a bridle on the jaws of the peoples to send them astray).

30.verse: The LORD will make his glorious voice heard, and let it be seen how his arm descends In raging fury and flame of consuming fire, in driving storm and hail.

31.verse: When the LORD speaks, Assyria will be shattered, as he strikes with the rod;

32.verse: While at every sweep of the rod which the LORD will bring down on him in punishment,

29.verse: You will sing as on a night when a feast is observed, And be merry of heart, as one marching along with a flute Toward the mountain of the LORD, toward the Rock of Israel, accompanied by the timbrels and lyres.

33.verse: For the pyre has long been ready, prepared for the king; Broad and deep it is piled with dry grass and wood in abundance, And the breath of the LORD, like a stream of sulphur, will set it afire.

annotations.1: [6] Flying saraph: see note on Numbers 21:6.
annotations.2: [7] Rahab: Egypt, here as elsewhere (cf Psalm 87:4), is compared to the stormy, impetuous sea monster (cf Isaiah 51:9; Job 26:12; Psalm 89:11), which yet, when asked for aid by Judah, becomes silent, quelled
annotations.3: [8] Isaiah will write down his condemnation of the people so that ( Isaiah 30:12-18) its fulfillment may afterward be admitted
annotations.4: [20] Teacher: God, who in the past taught in a veiled manner through his prophets, will in future help them to understand his teaching clearly. This was eminently true when the Son of God became Man
annotations.5: [27-33] God's punishment of Assyria. The name of the LORD: God himself; cf Psalm 20:2
annotations.6: [29-33] Pyre: on which the corpse of the king of Assyria is burned. This is the occasion of festal rejoicing for the Israelites, who are now free from his yoke

1.verse: Ah, land of buzzing insects, beyond the rivers of Ethiopia,

2.verse: Sending ambassadors by sea, in papyrus boats on the waters! Go, swift messengers, to a nation tall and bronzed, To a people dreaded near and far, a nation strong and conquering, whose land is washed by rivers.

3.verse: All you who inhabit the world, who dwell on earth, When the signal is raised on the mountain, look! When the trumpet blows, listen!

4.verse: For thus says the LORD to me: I will quietly look on from where I dwell, Like the glowing heat of sunshine, like a cloud of dew at harvest time.

5.verse: Before the vintage, when the flowering is ended, and the blooms are succeeded by ripening grapes, Then comes the cutting of branches with pruning hooks and the discarding of the lopped-off shoots.

6.verse: They shall all be left to the mountain birds of prey, and to the beasts in the land; The birds of prey shall summer on them and on them all the beasts of the earth shall winter.

7.verse: Then will gifts be brought to the LORD of hosts from a people tall and bronzed, from a people dreaded near and far, a nation strong and conquering, whose land is washed by rivers - to Mount Zion where dwells the name of the LORD of hosts

annotations.1: [1-2] Papyrus boats: light and serviceable vessels made of bundles of papyrus stalks and sealed with pitch. Egypt, ruled by a dynasty from Ethiopia, had invited Judah to join a coalition against Assyria, but Isaiah bade the ambassadors return to their own people
annotations.2: [1] Land of buzzing insects: the region of the Upper Nile where these multiplied with great rapidity.

1.verse: Bel bows down, Nebo stoops, their idols are upon beasts and cattle; They must be borne up on shoulders, carried as burdens by the weary.

2.verse: They stoop and bow down together; unable to save those who bear them, they too go into captivity.

3.verse: Hear me, O house of Jacob, all who remain of the house of Israel, My burden since your birth, whom I have carried from your infancy.

4.verse: Even to your old age I am the same, even when your hair is gray I will bear you; It is I who have done this, I who will continue, and I who will carry you to safety.

5.verse: Whom would you compare me with, as an equal, or match me against, as though we were alike?

6.verse: There are those who pour out gold from a purse and weigh out silver on the scales; Then they hire a goldsmith to make it into a god before which they fall down in worship.

7.verse: They lift it to their shoulders to carry; when they set it in place again, it stays, and does not move from the spot. Although they cry out to it, it cannot answer; it delivers no one from distress.

8.verse: Remember this and be firm, bear it well in mind, you rebels; remember the former things, those long ago:

9.verse: I am God, there is no other; I am God, there is none like me.

10.verse: At the beginning I foretell the outcome; in advance, things not yet done. I say that my plan shall stand, I accomplish my every purpose.

11.verse: I call from the east a bird of prey, from a distant land, one to carry out my plan. Yes, I have spoken, I will accomplish it; I have planned it, and I will do it.

12.verse: Listen to me, you fainthearted, you who seem far from the victory of justice:

13.verse: I am bringing on my justice, it is not far off, my salvation shall not tarry; I will put salvation within Zion, and give to Israel my glory.

annotations.1: [1] Bel . . . Nebo: gods of Babylon; their complete helplessness is here contrasted with God's omnipotence.
annotations.2: [11] From the east a bird of prey: Cyrus; cf Isaiah 41:2-4

1.verse: The just man perishes, but no one takes it to heart; Devout men are swept away, with no one giving it a thought. Though he is taken away from the presence of evil, the just man

2.verse: enters into peace; There is rest on his couch for the sincere, straightforward man.

3.verse: But you, draw near, you sons of a sorceress, adulterous, wanton race!

4.verse: Of whom do you make sport, at whom do you open wide your mouth, and put out your tongue? Are you not rebellious children, a worthless race;

5.verse: You who are in heat among the terebinths, under every green tree; You who immolate children in the wadies, behind the crevices in the cliffs?

6.verse: Among the smooth stones of the wadi is your portion, these are your lot; To these you poured out libations, and brought offerings. Should I decide not to punish these things?

7.verse: Upon a high and lofty mountain you made your bed, and there you went up to offer sacrifice.

8.verse: Behind the door and the doorpost you placed your indecent symbol. Deserting me, you spread out your high, wide bed; And of those whose embraces you love you carved the symbol and gazed upon it

9.verse: While you approached the king with scented oil, and multiplied your perfumes; While you sent your ambassadors far away, down even to the nether world.

10.verse: Though worn out by your many misdeeds, you never said, "It is hopeless"; New strength you found, and so you did not weaken.

11.verse: Of whom were you afraid? Whom did you fear, that you became false And did not remember me or give me any thought? Was I to remain silent and unseeing, so that you would not have me to fear?

12.verse: I will expose your justice and your works;

13.verse: They shall not help you when you cry out, nor save you in your distress. All these the wind shall carry off, the breeze shall bear away; But he who takes refuge in me shall inherit the land, and possess my holy mountain.

14.verse: Build up, build up, prepare the way, remove the stumbling blocks from my people's path.

15.verse: For thus says he who is high and exalted, living eternally, whose name is the Holy One: On high I dwell, and in holiness, and with the crushed and dejected in spirit, To revive the spirits of the dejected, to revive the hearts of the crushed.

16.verse: I will not accuse forever, nor always be angry; For their spirits would faint before me, the souls that I have made.

17.verse: Because of their wicked avarice I was angry, and struck them, hiding myself in wrath, as they went their own rebellious way.

18.verse: I saw their ways, but I will heal them and lead them; I will give full comfort to them and to those who mourn for them,

19.verse: I, the Creator, who gave them life. Peace, peace to the far and the near, says the LORD; and I will heal them.

20.verse: But the wicked are like the tossing sea which cannot be calmed, And its waters cast up mud and filth.

21.verse: No peace for the wicked! says my God.

annotations.1: [6] Smooth stones: the Hebrew word for this expression has the same consonants as the word for "portion"; instead of making the Lord their portion (cf Psalm 16:5), the people adored slabs of stone which they took from the streambeds in valleys and set up as idols; cf Jeremiah 3:9. Therefore, it is implied, they will be swept away as by a sudden torrent of waters carrying them down the rocky-bottomed gorge to destruction and death without burial.
annotations.2: [9] The king: the pagan god Moloch. Ambassadors: children sent to him through a sacrificial death
annotations.3: [12] Justice: here used ironically
annotations.4: [13] All these: the wicked mentioned in 57:3-10

1.verse: Woe to the majestic garland of the drunkard Ephraim, To the fading blooms of his glorious beauty, on the head of him who is stupefied with wine.

2.verse: Behold, the LORD has a strong one and a mighty, who, like a downpour of hail, a destructive storm, Like a flood of water, great and overflowing, levels to the ground with violence;

3.verse: With feet that will trample the majestic garland of the drunkard Ephraim.

4.verse: The fading blooms of his glorious beauty on the head of the fertile valley Will be like an early fig before summer: when a man sees it, he picks and swallows it at once.

5.verse: On that day the LORD of hosts will be a glorious crown And a brilliant diadem to the remnant of his people,

6.verse: A spirit of justice to him who sits in judgment, And strength to those who turn back the battle at the gate.

7.verse: But these also stagger from wine and stumble from strong drink: Priest and prophet stagger from strong drink, overpowered by wine; Led astray by strong drink, staggering in their visions, tottering when giving judgment.

8.verse: Yes, all the tables are covered with filthy vomit, with no place left clean.

9.verse: "To whom would he impart knowledge? To whom would he convey the message? To those just weaned from milk, those taken from the breast?

10.verse: For he says, 'Command on command, command on command, rule on rule, rule on rule, here a little, there a little!'"

11.verse: Yes, with stammering lips and in a strange language he will speak to this people

12.verse: to whom he said: This is the resting place, give rest to the weary; Here is repose - but they would not listen.

13.verse: So for them the word of the LORD shall be: "Command on command, command on command, Rule on rule, rule on rule, here a little, there a little!" So that when they walk, they stumble backward, broken, ensnared, and captured.

14.verse: Therefore, hear the word of the LORD, you arrogant, who rule this people in Jerusalem:

15.verse: Because you say, "We have made a covenant with death, and with the nether world we have made a pact; When the overwhelming scourge passes, it will not reach us; For we have made lies our refuge, and in falsehood we have found a hiding place," -

16.verse: Therefore, thus says the Lord GOD: See, I am laying a stone in Zion, a stone that has been tested, A precious cornerstone as a sure foundation; he who puts his faith in it shall not be shaken.

17.verse: I will make of right a measuring line, of justice a level. - Hail shall sweep away the refuge of lies, and waters shall flood the hiding place.

18.verse: Your covenant with death shall be canceled and your pact with the nether world shall not stand. When the overwhelming scourge passes, you shall be trampled down by it.

19.verse: Whenever it passes, it shall take you; morning after morning it shall pass, By day and by night; terror alone shall convey the message.

20.verse: For the bed shall be too short to stretch out in, and the cover too narrow to wrap in.

21.verse: For the LORD shall rise up as on Mount Perazim, bestir himself as in the Valley of Gibeon, To carry out his work, his singular work, to perform his deed, his strange deed.

22.verse: Now, be arrogant no more lest your bonds be tightened, For I have heard from the Lord, the GOD of hosts, the destruction decreed for the whole earth.

23.verse: Give ear and hear my voice, pay attention and listen to what I say:

24.verse: Is the plowman forever plowing, always loosening and harrowing his land for planting?

25.verse: When he has leveled the surface, does he not scatter gith and sow cumin, Put in wheat and barley, with spelt as its border?

26.verse: He has learned this rule, instructed by his God.

27.verse: Gith is not threshed with a sledge, nor does a cartwheel roll over cumin. But gith is beaten out with a staff, and cumin crushed for food with a rod.

28.verse: No, he does not thresh it unendingly, nor does he crush it with his noisy cartwheels and horses.

29.verse: This too comes from the LORD of hosts; wonderful is his counsel and great his wisdom.

annotations.1: [1] Ephraim: the northern kingdom. Its capital, Samaria, was built upon a hill, suggestive of a majestic garland adorning the head of the drunken kingdom.
annotations.2: [2] A strong one and a mighty: Assyria
annotations.3: [9-10] The words of those who ridicule Isaiah. The Hebrew of Isaiah 28:10 by its very sound, conveys the idea of mocking imitation of what the prophet says, as though he spoke like a stammering child: SAU LASAU, SAU LASAU, CAU LACAU, CAU LACAU, ZE'ER SHAM, ZE'ER SHAM. But in v 13 God repeats these words in deadly earnest, putting them in the mouth of the victorious pagan army
annotations.4: [11] God will answer the mockers and defend Isaiah. Strange language: spoken by the invading army
annotations.5: [15,18] A covenant with death, and with the nether world: an alliance with foreign powers, such as Egypt and Babylon, to prevent death and destruction. Have made lies . . . a hiding place: this confidence in human aid proves to be false and deceitful, incapable of averting the dreaded disaster. Overwhelming scourge: the flood of the Assyrian invasion; cf Isaiah 8:7-8
annotations.6: [16] A stone in Zion: the true and sure foundation of salvation promised by God to the Davidic dynasty (cf Isaiah 7:13-16; 9:1-6), which the Apostles saw fulfilled in Christ the universal Savior; cf 1 Peter 2:6-8; Romans 9:33; 10:9-11. Cornerstone: the assurance of salvation rejected by Israel in the prophet's time, is reflected by the psalmist ( Psalm 118:22) and fulfilled in the Person of Christ; cf Matthew 21:42; Luke 20:17; Acts 4:11; Romans 9:33; 1 Peter 2:7
annotations.7: [21] Mount Perazim . . . Valley of Gibeon: where David defeated the Philistines; cf 2 Sam 5:20, 25; 1 Chron 14:11, 16
annotations.8: [23-29] The practical variation of the farmer's work taught him by God reflects God's dealing with his people, wisely adapted to circumstances; he does not crush their weakness altogether; cf Isaiah 29
annotations.9: [25] Gith . . . cumin: herbs used in seasoning food. Spelt: a variety of wheat

1.verse: Here is my servant whom I uphold, my chosen one with whom I am pleased, Upon whom I have put my spirit; he shall bring forth justice to the nations,

2.verse: Not crying out, not shouting, not making his voice heard in the street.

3.verse: A bruised reed he shall not break, and a smoldering wick he shall not quench,

4.verse: Until he establishes justice on the earth; the coastlands will wait for his teaching.

5.verse: Thus says God, the LORD, who created the heavens and stretched them out, who spreads out the earth with its crops, Who gives breath to its people and spirit to those who walk on it:

6.verse: I, the LORD, have called you for the victory of justice, I have grasped you by the hand; I formed you, and set you as a covenant of the people, a light for the nations,

7.verse: To open the eyes of the blind, to bring out prisoners from confinement, and from the dungeon, those who live in darkness.

8.verse: I am the LORD, this is my name; my glory I give to no other, nor my praise to idols.

9.verse: See, the earlier things have come to pass, new ones I now foretell; Before they spring into being, I announce them to you.

10.verse: Sing to the LORD a new song, his praise from the end of the earth: Let the sea and what fills it resound, the coastlands, and those who dwell in them.

11.verse: Let the steppe and its cities cry out, the villages where Kedar dwells; Let the inhabitants of Sela exult, and shout from the top of the mountains.

12.verse: Let them give glory to the LORD, and utter his praise in the coastlands.

13.verse: The LORD goes forth like a hero, like a warrior he stirs up his ardor; He shouts out his battle cry, against his enemies he shows his might:

14.verse: I have looked away, and kept silence, I have said nothing, holding myself in; But now, I cry out as a woman in labor, gasping and panting.

15.verse: I will lay waste mountains and hills, all their herbage I will dry up; I will turn the rivers into marshes, and the marshes I will dry up.

16.verse: I will lead the blind on their journey; by paths unknown I will guide them. I will turn darkness into light before them, and make crooked ways straight. These things I do for them, and I will not forsake them.

17.verse: They shall be turned back in utter shame who trust in idols; Who say to molten images, "You are our gods."

18.verse: You who are deaf, listen, you who are blind, look and see!

19.verse: Who is blind but my servant, or deaf like the messenger I send?

20.verse: You see many things without taking note; your ears are open, but without hearing.

21.verse: Though it pleased the LORD in his justice to make his law great and glorious,

22.verse: This is a people despoiled and plundered, all of them trapped in holes, hidden away in prisons. They are taken as booty, with no one to rescue them, as spoil, with no one to demand their return.

23.verse: Who of you gives ear to this? Who listens and pays heed for the time to come?

24.verse: Who was it that gave Jacob to be plundered, Israel to the despoilers? Was it not the LORD, against whom we have sinned? In his ways they refused to walk, his law they disobeyed.

25.verse: So he poured out wrath upon them, his anger, and the fury of battle; It blazed round about them, yet they did not realize, it burned them, but they took it not to heart.

annotations.1: [1-4] Servant: there are three other "Servant-of-the-Lord" oracles, 49:1-7; 50:4-11; 52:13- 53:12. Many identifications have been proposed, e.g., historical Israel, ideal Israel, an Old Testament historical character before or during the lifetime of the prophet, the prophet himself. The New Testament and Christian tradition, however, have seen a fulfillment of these prophecies in Jesus Christ.
annotations.2: [3] A reference to the mercy of Christ
annotations.3: [4] Coastlands: the lands of the Mediterranean. In the Old Testament the word often refers to the pagan lands of the west
annotations.4: [11] Kedar: cf footnote to Isaiah 21:16. Sela: Petra, the capital of Edom
annotations.5: [18-20] Because of their unbelief, the Lord rebukes his people, whom he calls his servant, his messenger
annotations.6: [22] A people: Israel in exile

1.verse: In the fourteenth year of King Hezekiah, Sennacherib, king of Assyria, went on an expedition against all the fortified cities of Judah and captured them.

2.verse: From Lachish the king of Assyria sent his commander with a great army to King Hezekiah in Jerusalem. When he stopped at the conduit of the upper pool, on the highway of the fuller's field,

3.verse: there came out to him the master of the palace, Eliakim, son of Hilkiah, and Shebna the scribe, and the herald Joah, son of Asaph.

4.verse: The commander said to them, "Tell King Hezekiah: Thus says the great king, the king of Assyria, 'On what do you base this confidence of yours?

5.verse: Do you think mere words substitute for strategy and might in war? On whom, then, do you rely, that you rebel against me?

6.verse: This Egypt, the staff on which you rely, is in fact a broken reed which pierces the hand of anyone who leans on it. That is what Pharaoh, king of Egypt, is to all who rely on him.

7.verse: But if you say to me: "We rely on the LORD, our God," is not he the one whose high places and altars Hezekiah removed, commanding Judah and Jerusalem to worship before this altar?'

8.verse: "Now, make a wager with my lord the king of Assyria: 'I will give you two thousand horses, if you can put riders on them.'

9.verse: How then can you repulse even one of the least servants of my lord? And yet you rely on Egypt for chariots and horsemen!

10.verse: 'Was it without the LORD'S will that I have come up to destroy this land? The LORD said to me, "Go up and destroy that land!"'"

11.verse: Then Eliakim and Shebna and Joah said to the commander, "Please speak to your servants in Aramaic; we understand it. Do not speak to us in Judean within earshot of the people who are on the wall."

12.verse: But the commander replied, "Was it to you and your master that my lord sent me to speak these words? Was it not rather to the men sitting on the wall, who, with you, will have to eat their own excrement and drink their own urine?"

13.verse: Then the commander stepped forward and cried out in a loud voice in Judean, "Listen to the words of the great king, the king of Assyria.

14.verse: Thus says the king: 'Do not let Hezekiah deceive you, since he cannot deliver you.

15.verse: Let not Hezekiah induce you to rely on the LORD, saying, "The LORD will surely save us; this city will not be handed over to the king of Assyria."'

16.verse: Do not listen to Hezekiah, for the king of Assyria says: 'Make peace with me and surrender! Then each of you will eat of his own vine and of his own fig tree, and drink the water of his own cistern,

17.verse: until I come to take you to a land like your own, a land of grain and wine, of bread and vineyards.

18.verse: Do not let Hezekiah seduce you by saying, "The LORD will save us." Has any of the gods of the nations ever rescued his land from the hand of the king of Assyria?

19.verse: Where are the gods of Hamath and Arpad? Where are the gods of Sepharvaim? Where are the gods of Samaria? Have they saved Samaria from my hand?

annotations.1: [ 36:1- 39:8] Except for 38:9-20 this historical appendix describing the siege, etc., is paralleled in 2 Kings 18:13- 20:19 which, however, has certain details proper to itself. The events are also recorded in substantially the same way in the cuneiform inscriptions of Sennacherib.
annotations.2: [7] The Assyrians pretend that Hezekiah's removal of the high places and altars (illegal sanctuaries) was taken by the Lord as an insult. 1.verse: Who would believe what we have heard? To whom has the arm of the LORD been revealed?

2.verse: He grew up like a sapling before him, like a shoot from the parched earth; There was in him no stately bearing to make us look at him, nor appearance that would attract us to him.

3.verse: He was spurned and avoided by men, a man of suffering, accustomed to infirmity, One of those from whom men hide their faces, spurned, and we held him in no esteem.

4.verse: Yet it was our infirmities that he bore, our sufferings that he endured, While we thought of him as stricken, as one smitten by God and afflicted.

5.verse: But he was pierced for our offenses, crushed for our sins, Upon him was the chastisement that makes us whole, by his stripes we were healed.

6.verse: We had all gone astray like sheep, each following his own way; But the LORD laid upon him the guilt of us all.

7.verse: Though he was harshly treated, he submitted and opened not his mouth; Like a lamb led to the slaughter or a sheep before the shearers, he was silent and opened not his mouth.

8.verse: Oppressed and condemned, he was taken away, and who would have thought any more of his destiny? When he was cut off from the land of the living, and smitten for the sin of his people,

9.verse: A grave was assigned him among the wicked and a burial place with evildoers, Though he had done no wrong nor spoken any falsehood.

10.verse: (But the LORD was pleased to crush him in infirmity.) If he gives his life as an offering for sin, he shall see his descendants in a long life, and the will of the LORD shall be accomplished through him.

11.verse: Because of his affliction he shall see the light in fullness of days; Through his suffering, my servant shall justify many, and their guilt he shall bear.

12.verse: Therefore I will give him his portion among the great, and he shall divide the spoils with the mighty, Because he surrendered himself to death and was counted among the wicked; And he shall take away the sins of many, and win pardon for their offenses.

1.verse: Thus says the LORD: Observe what is right, do what is just; for my salvation is about to come, my justice, about to be revealed.

2.verse: Happy is the man who does this, the son of man who holds to it; Who keeps the sabbath free from profanation, and his hand from any evildoing.

3.verse: Let not the foreigner say, when he would join himself to the LORD, "The LORD will surely exclude me from his people"; Nor let the eunuch say, "See, I am a dry tree."

4.verse: For thus says the LORD: To the eunuchs who observe my sabbaths and choose what pleases me and hold fast to my covenant,

5.verse: I will give, in my house and within my walls, a monument and a name Better than sons and daughters; an eternal, imperishable name will I give them.

6.verse: And the foreigners who join themselves to the LORD, ministering to him, Loving the name of the LORD, and becoming his servants - All who keep the sabbath free from profanation and hold to my covenant,

7.verse: Them I will bring to my holy mountain and make joyful in my house of prayer; Their holocausts and sacrifices will be acceptable on my altar, For my house shall be called a house of prayer for all peoples.

8.verse: Thus says the Lord GOD, who gathers the dispersed of Israel: Others will I gather to him besides those already gathered.

9.verse: All you wild beasts of the field, come and eat, all you beasts in the forest!

10.verse: My watchmen are blind, all of them unaware; They are all dumb dogs, they cannot bark; Dreaming as they lie there, loving their sleep.

11.verse: They are relentless dogs, they know not when they have enough. These are the shepherds who know no discretion; Each of them goes his own way, every one of them to his own gain:

12.verse: "Come, I will fetch some wine; let us carouse with strong drink, And tomorrow will be like today, or even greater."

annotations.1: [1-8] Participation in the future messianic salvation is offered to all who believe in the Lord and keep his commandments, regardless of origin or social condition.
annotations.2: [3] Eunuchs had originally been excluded from the community of the Lord; cf Deut 23:2; Wisdom 3:14. Dry tree: unable to produce the fruit of offspring
annotations.3: [5] A monument and a name: a memorial inscription to prevent oblivion for one who had no children; cf 2 Sam 18:18; Nehemiah 7:15; 13:14
annotations.4: [ 56:9- 57:13] This section is apparently preexilic, written in the manner of the older prophets who condemned the pagan rites of Baal worship
annotations.5: [9] Wild beasts: foreign nations, which are invited to come and ravage Israel

1.verse: The spirit of the Lord GOD is upon me, because the LORD has anointed me; He has sent me to bring glad tidings to the lowly, to heal the brokenhearted, To proclaim liberty to the captives and release to the prisoners,

2.verse: To announce a year of favor from the LORD and a day of vindication by our God, to comfort all who mourn;

3.verse: To place on those who mourn in Zion a diadem instead of ashes, To give them oil of gladness in place of mourning, a glorious mantle instead of a listless spirit. They will be called oaks of justice, planted by the LORD to show his glory.

3.verse: People who provoke me continually, to my face, Offering sacrifices in the groves and burning incense on bricks,

1.verse: In those days, when Hezekiah was mortally ill, the prophet Isaiah, son of Amoz, came and said to him: "Thus says the LORD: Put your house in order, for you are about to die; you shall not recover."

2.verse: Then Hezekiah turned his face to the wall and prayed to the LORD:

3.verse: "O LORD, remember how faithfully and wholeheartedly I conducted myself in your presence, doing what was pleasing to you!" And Hezekiah wept bitterly.

4.verse: Then the word of the LORD came to Isaiah:

5.verse: "Go, tell Hezekiah: Thus says the LORD, the God of your father David: I have heard your prayer and seen your tears. I will heal you: in three days you shall go up to the LORD'S temple; I will add fifteen years to your life.

6.verse: I will rescue you and this city from the hand of the king of Assyria; I will be a shield to this city."

12.verse: My dwelling, like a shepherd's tent, is struck down and borne away from me; You have folded up my life, like a weaver who severs the last thread. Day and night you give me over to torment;

13.verse: I cry out until the dawn. Like a lion he breaks all my bones; (day and night you give me over to torment).

14.verse: Like a swallow I utter shrill cries; I moan like a dove. My eyes grow weak, gazing heavenward: O Lord, I am in straits; be my surety!

15.verse: What am I to say or tell him? He has done it! I shall go on through all my years despite the bitterness of my soul.

16.verse: Those live whom the LORD protects; yours. . . the life of my spirit. You have given me health and life;

17.verse: thus is my bitterness transformed into peace. You have preserved my life from the pit of destruction, When you cast behind your back all my sins.

18.verse: For it is not the nether world that gives you thanks, nor death that praises you; Neither do those who go down into the pit await your kindness.

19.verse: The living, the living give you thanks, as I do today. Fathers declare to their sons, O God, your faithfulness.

20.verse: The LORD is our savior; we shall sing to stringed instruments In the house of the LORD all the days of our life.

annotations.1: [ 38:1- 39:8] The events of this section-sickness and recovery of Hezekiah, embassy of Merodach-baladan-point forward to Babylon (cc 40-66). They occurred prior to the events of Isaiah 36:1- 37:38 which point back to Assyria ( Isaiah 1:1- 35:10)
annotations.2: [1] In those days: a time prior to the siege of Jerusalem in 701 B.C.
annotations.3: [5] Since Hezekiah died in 687 B.C., this sickness of his seems to have been in 702 B.C., that is, fifteen years before
annotations.4: [8] Stairway to the terrace of Ahaz: this interpretation is based on a reading of the Hebrew text revised according to the Dead Sea Scroll of Isaiah; cf 2 Kings 23:12. Many translatethe phrase as "steps of Ahaz" and understand this as referring to a sundial
annotations.5: [10] In the noontime of life: long before the end of a full span of life; cf Psalm 55:23; 102:24
annotations.6: [11] See the LORD: go to the Temple and take part in its service
annotations.7: [12] These two metaphors emphasize the suddenness and finality of death
annotations.8: [15] What am I to say or tell him?: a rhetorical question, as if the poet were at a loss in giving fitting expression to his gratitude; cf Psalm 116:12. He has done it: accomplished the cure. Despite the bitterness: even though the one praying was previously so dejected
annotations.9: [16] Yours . . . the life of my spirit: the current Hebrew text is corrupt. The revised Latin psalter renders it: "you have revived my soul."
annotations.10: [17] You cast behind your back all my sins: figurative language to express the divine forgiveness of sins, as if God no longer saw or cared about them. This expression is ordinarily used of men forgetting God; cf 1 Kings 14:9; Ezekiel 23:35; Psalm 50:17

2.verse: Shake off the dust, ascend to the throne, Jerusalem; Loose the bonds from your neck, O captive daughter Zion!

3.verse: For thus says the LORD: You were sold for nothing, and without money you shall be redeemed.

5.verse: But now, what am I to do here? says the LORD. My people have been taken away without redress; their rulers make a boast of it, says the LORD; all the day my name is constantly reviled.

6.verse: Therefore on that day my people shall know my renown, that it is I who have foretold it. Here I am!

7.verse: How beautiful upon the mountains are the feet of him who brings glad tidings, Announcing peace, bearing good news, announcing salvation, and saying to Zion, "Your God is King!"

8.verse: Hark! Your watchmen raise a cry, together they shout for joy, For they see directly, before their eyes, the LORD restoring Zion.

9.verse: Break out together in song, O ruins of Jerusalem! For the LORD comforts his people, he redeems Jerusalem.

10.verse: The LORD has bared his holy arm in the sight of all the nations; All the ends of the earth will behold the salvation of our God.

11.verse: Depart, depart, come forth from there, touch nothing unclean! Out from there! Purify yourselves, you who carry the vessels of the LORD.

12.verse: Yet not in fearful haste will you come out, nor leave in headlong flight, For the LORD comes before you, and your rear guard is the God of Israel.

13.verse: See, my servant shall prosper, he shall be raised high and greatly exalted.

14.verse: Even as many were amazed at him - so marred was his look beyond that of man, and his appearance beyond that of mortals - &nbsp

15.verse: So shall he startle many nations, because of him kings shall stand speechless; For those who have not been told shall see, those who have not heard shall ponder it.

annotations.1: [7-10] God leads his people back from Babylon to Zion, from whose ruined walls watchmen . . . shout for joy; cf Romans 10:15.
annotations.2: [11] From there: from Babylon. Vessels of the LORD: taken to Babylon by Nebuchadnezzar, now carried back by the exiled priests returning in procession to Zion; cf Ezra 1:7
annotations.3: [ 52:13- 53:12] The last of the four "Servant-of-the-Lord" oracles. An extraordinary description of the sinless Servant, who by his voluntary suffering atones for the sins of his people, and saves them from just punishment at the hands of God. Only in Jesus Christ is the prophecy perfectly fulfilled
